reviews.review_text: Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is the follow up to Borderlands 2 and fallows on the rise of Handsome Jack. But will you want to play it ?  Borderlands TPS takes place after the events of Borderlands and before the events of Borderlands 2 and follows on four new vault hunters. Athena, Wilhelm, Nisha and Claptrap get a message from a hyperion worker who happens to be Handsome Jack. After the Dahl soldiers take over the space station they try to destroy the moon of Elpis and it's up to you to stop them.  Gameplay is identical to Borderlands 2. The only new thing is the new Oxygen system. You have a bar which starts to drain when you are outside the oxygen field for too long. Then you start to suffocate. You can also use the double jump to get on higher platforms. You can avoid the oxygen system by picking Claptrap as your character. The new abilities are awesome and all of them are very fun to use.  Graphics are stunning as ever. They look awesome and all the colors are very nice to look at. The textures are kind of mediocre and some of the character models look very bad. Overall the game looks great apart from minor flaws.  Audio is pretty bad. The game's audio for me stopped during firefights and I couldn't hear anything the characters would say to me and sometimes the Echo Com screen didn't transfer the dialogue and I couldn't hear anything which wasn't a problem in Borderlands 2. The soundtrack is alright, there are some great songs but a lot of them are kind of mediocre.  The game is pretty easy for the most part until the final chapter where there is a massive difficulty spike and the final boss solo is incredibly hard. The boss fights are very team oriented meaning the game expected you to play with people from the start.   Level Design in some parts is abysmal it took me massive amounts of understanding where my objective was and where the side quest start. This by far the worst level design in a borderlands game.  The game took me 22 hours to complete every quest and to get to level 27. The game like other Borderlands games has tons of replay value with different vault hunter modes and trying out other characters and of course not to mention the DLC which I will have to check out one day.  The game is pretty stable from the most part. There where some parts where the game wouldn't open a certain door to progress through a quest but a quick reload always fixed the problem.  Overall this game is not as good as the other titles in the series and without a doubt not worth it at the full price. I am a massive Borderlands fan and Pre Ordered this game once I saw it and I can safely say it wasn't a bad game but it's not as good as the other Borderlands games. For other people only buy this on a sale. It has a lot of horrible side quests but this is an overall good game and I highly suggest you to check it out on a sale. I give Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel a 7/10  For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page  here  - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

This game is like the cute, younger, and less developed sister of borderlands 2. She's smaller and hasn't really grown into the goddess that is bl2, but the genes are there and she makes up for with a degree of novelty and eagerness.

It's fun, but not quite as fun as Borderlands 2.   The story is a bit weak, the NPCs are a little flat, and the humor feels meh. I'm just guessing here, but a lot of it is because 2k Australia created it. They went heavy handed trying to infuse the game with Aussie-ness. Pickle, one of the NPCs, feels like such a terrible caricature. Cor! Blimey! He's one step away from Crocodile Dundee. (Edit: Scratch that. Apparently it's a Cockney accent. Still a bit much either way.) And sadly, because we're in space, incendiary just doesn't feel useful anymore. Some of the mechanics are terrible too. Trying to jump some of the gaps require more precision than necessary. And Deadlift, the second boss, is a lot tougher than he should be.   So why am I recommending the game? Because all the playable characters are well built. I've played everyone, including the expansion characters, save for Claptrap and loved each of their skill trees. In BL2, I didn't care much for Salavdor, Zer0, Gaige or Krieg. But the PS skills are nailing it. Also, cryo as an element is an awesome replacement for slag, which really only worked in teamplay anyway. And while jumping/boosting feels a little gimmicky, it's still fun to float around and bring down a butt-slam.  In short, as part of the series, it's a bit of a letdown. But if you can overlook that and pretend it's a one-off, it's still fun. Here's looking forward to Borderlands 3.

I was too harsh on my other review. While this is the worst Borderlands game out there, it is still a good game, not worth the $40, however. Borderlands: TPS takes place after the 1st game and before the 2nd game on Pandora's moon, Elpis.  PROS:   Get to learn the backstory of Jack, Moxxi, Athena, and a few others   Some of the new skill trees are fun   Good soundtrack   More dialogue than the 2nd, especially between the player and NPCs   Cryo element and Laser weapons are effective   Grinder can make new weapons that can't be found anywhere else  NEUTRAL:   Humor is Australian   Low gravity can be fun or tedious   The HUD is identical to BL2  CONS:   Story is shorter than the 2nd game (for double the price, too)   Not very memorable side characters   Color scheme is somewhat dull   Some of the main missions are tedious as hell (walking back and forth with very little action)   The writing is weaker here (although they still pull off a few good jokes here and there)    They removed the Slag element   7.5/10,  Get GOTY Borderlands 2 instead of this, same price with at least triple the content.   Old review for the people who are interested.

This game is really good.  A new hud and new visuals doesn't make a game, content does. And this game has a ton of content.  First of all, let me start with one thing. This game is surprsingly DARK compared to the last two Borderlands games. Prepare your morality.  Now that that's done, let's carry on.  PROS  +Borderlands The Pre-Sequel does not disappoint. I have to admit, at first I was super worried about dying of oxygen loss, but the devs were able to make it so losing your oxygen doesn't really make you worry. Oxygen is every where, and if you DO run out, your health depleted at around less than 1% per second, so it isn't a threat to you at all.  +The low gravity also helps a lot. The use of buttslams makes it more fun to flank enemies, and makes the combat even more fast-paced. Slams also work in places with oxygen, as long as the area doesn't have aritifcial gravity. This also helps for easy second winds. If you were to jump accross the area, and get shot down, chances are you'll land right close to another bunch of enemies. This gives you an indirect and accidental edge against enemies, which is also good. Additonally, certain oz-kits can make your low-g experience more fun and fluid, I personally use the air control ones.  +Now about lasers, one of the most advertised parts of the game. Let me put this straight, they're awesome, and really powerful. They also act as psuedo-gun types for each brand. You want Dahl Shotguns back? Have A LASER ONE THAT FIRES AROUND 3 LASER BOLTS PER SECOND. There are also different types such as the railguns, beams, and repeaters, but different manufacturers can give each weapon type an edge due to their special attributes.  +Cryo weapons are also fun, and not just in the visual kind of appeal. It's more tactical than slag. Slag was just like 'shoot enemies with this and then hit them with this'. It even stole corossion's power, which made it even crappier. But cryo is super fun to use. The simple charm of butt stomping a single enemy ( EVEN MORE FUN WITH A TEAM) just puts a smile on my face.  Also, A LOT OF unique weapons with red text can compete with legendary weapons. Like AN EXPLOSIVE JAKOBS SHOTGUN.  Now we have the CONS. Every game has them.  -Let's start with a really annoying one, the checkpoints aren't kind. The maps are bigger for verticality purposes, but some checkpoints can be too far enough that they end up stingy and unforgiving.   -Next, the vehicles. While the stingray is a pretty fun vehicle to use, I can't help but feel disappointed in the lack of variety. The moon buggy is okay at best, although it's more of the same with classic Borderlands vehicles.  -Nisha's whip is terrible, unless you get the Law and Order skill tree capstone. Don't expect to melee a lot with her.  -The side missions are the same with past missions, where you have to go and kill the thing while getting the other thing. Personally, I don't mind this since Pre-Sequel has the best combat in a Borderlands game so far, but other people might not.  ...Overall, Borderlands TPS is a great time. Unless your emotions will get the better of you SINCE THIS GAME IS PRETTY DARK.  An 8 out of 10.

A big step backwards for the Borderlands franchise. While a few things were quite well done, particularly class design, bugs were a much bigger problem than in previous installments of the series, and gameplay suffered in multiple ways. Side quests were badly written and often tiresome, attention to making them feel cohesive was lacking, and boss fights were the worst in the series, with the possible exception of the final boss. Both previous Borderlands games, I finished, did my second playthrough, and jumped on the campaign DLCs. In the case of Pre-Sequel, I had to force myself to finish it, and I'm not sure if I want to get DLC in the hopes that it'll be better than the base game, or just buy Tales from the Borderlands, to make clear to Gearbox that my fondness for the franchise is intact, but that shoddy work won't be rewarded.
Still a better game than Destiny.

The content of a Borderlands 2 DLC being marketed and sold as a separate game. It may be worth half the price, but that is still only half the asking price! In addition, they intend to sell DLC on top of this DLC, making it a clear cash cow. Perhaps it would be worth the money if this future DLC were a part of the package, but it is not.  Several issues from Borderlands 2 are addressed, others left as-is, and new issue are introduced. The content is nice, but not terribly deep --- similar to the Torgue or Tiny Tina DLCs. The maps are, franky, proorly organised and oftentimes frustratingly buggy, with invisible walls more prevalent than past Borderlands experiences. The side-quests are also horridly arranged, often having to reclear an area to get the mission, return to a second area you need to reclear to undertake the mission, then back fo the first location to, yup, reclear it again to turn in the mission!  Cryo replacing Slag makes for a more interesting mechanic and Lasers are an interesting new weapon, though I could take or leave them personally. The new vault hunters are interesting and seem well designed. The plot fills a few gaps from Borderlands 2 and has a few laughs, though the humour is definitely worse than Borderlands 2. The voice acting makes refernce to different Australian and English peoples, though most gamers will not get these references and many will find the dialogue incomprehensible.

Bad game? No. Short Game? Oh most definetly. Un creative and 99% copy pasted? Mhm.  I understand that this is the gap between 1 and 2, but the thing is, take away the side missions in this game, its so short it could of been another DLC pack for BL2. and *spoilers* It might as well be considering that its told in a flashback. You go to the moon, shut down a singnal, kill the boss, get betrayed, find a vault and get punched in the face. thats this games story. Besides like, 4 legendary guns, cryo, lasers and low grav, nothing new was added that i could see. All but 4 or so legendaries have been copy pasted or renamed and reskined, oxygen isnt even a problem in this game considering you suffocate so god damn slowly, characters are bland, (aside from athena imo) skills are un interesting and a lot of the characters are just plain annoying. Janey and Pickle are the biggest offenders imo.   Is it a bad game? No. Does it feel like a rushed game to meet the crying needs of fans? Oh hell yes. Is it worth the price tag? Not even close. 30$ at most is what i would put this for. Choice is yours.

Being Aussie, even I cringed at the overdone accents and bogan humour.  This game reminds me a lot of the Assassins Creed Franchise - Assassins Creed 1 & 2 were amazing with the amount of development time and thought put into them. Then the yearly release cycles began just to give impatient fans a fix, resulting in AC: Brotherhood and Revelations. Whilst not bad games on their own right, they were not memorable either.  BL:TPS is like my AC: Brotherhood and Revelations. I prefer quality over quantity and would have been happy waiting a few years for Borderlands 3. If it weren't for console limitations preventing further DLC on Bordrlands 2, I would have preferred to use the money I spent on BL:TPS to support more Borderlands 2 content.

Really disappointing. The lack of fast travel stations will drive you insane- get ready to walk everywhere, all the time. It feels like a lazy attempt to lengthen the game. The missions generally feel like poor copies of the least fun missions from Borderlands 2. There's literally not one thing about this game that is in any way an improvement over Borderlands 2. The stingray vehicle is legitimately broken. The enemies are boring. There is no challenge in playing this game. Just save your money, don't waste your time, and wait for the next real Borderlands release from Gearbox, not this outsourced crap that 2k Australia produced.

Myself and 3 friends all bought this at the same time, and none of us are playing it past a couple hours. Save your money, it's an expansion pack at BEST (and not a fun one), don' t pay more than $5-10.

-Quick Review-   Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is FPS RPG developed by 2K Australia and Gearbox Software, and released in 2014. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is pretty much Borderlands 2 but on the moon/station seen over Pandora. If you're not sure if you'll like borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, go give Borderlands 2 a try.    -Detailed breakdown review-    Story:  Borderlands: The Pre-sequel takes place between the first Borderlands game and Borderlands 2. If you couldn't figure that out for yourself based on the colorful word-play.  (Is a Pre-Sequel even a thing? *googles* well seeing as the only results are Borderlands the Pre-Sequel)  To add a bit more clarification or to completely lose you: The story is actually taking place AFTER Borderlands 2, but in story format, as told by Athena  (A secret agent-type, gone rogue. You meet her in Borderlands 1's The Secret Armory of General Knoxx) .   For simplicity sake lets just say it's an 'in between' game. You play as one of Handsome Jacks henchmen and discover what eventually led to his turning to the dark side. Okay, not star wars, but the 'turning' aspect or 'corruption' felt very similar. You start out by working with a cheerful happy-go-lucky employee of Hyperion, and see him slowly descend into a paranoid power hungry shell of his former self.     Controls:  The controls feel pretty much the same as Borderlands 2, or generic FPS's, WASD to move, mouse to move the camera, keyboard rebinding is available, mouse wheel up or down to change weapons, or press 1,2,3,etc. I've always liked the controls in Borderlands games, simple straightforward, no keyboard piano playing.  But wait!  There is a few new changes ! Namely Gravity! If you're outside of a location that has artificial gravity  (inside a ship, indoors, in a base, etc)  you will float higher on your jumps. While definitely entertaining, and adding a whole new level of stress when you miss a long jump.  (have you fallen into the abyss slowly? It's agony!)  There's a new mechanic that you can also press CTRL (or whichever key you bind) to slam down onto the ground, or on top of enemies. A new gear slot will represent an air container which is necessary for all humans to survive in the vacuum of space but furthermore doubles as being used for double jumping in space.  (You can jump once, then jump again at the expense of air)  Enemies sometimes drop air canisters that will replenish some of your air, there are other locations where you can go to get oxygen filled up, buildings, and specific devices which create a force-field of air you can stand in.   Progression:  There are several sources you can get a sensation of progression in Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. The most obvious representation of progression is by story progression or level progression. After you finish the story you can repeat the story again to continue leveling until you reach the cap.  Or you can reroll another character, if you made the mistake of playing Claptrap on your first play through like I did. For those that don't know, even though claptrap is hilariously annoying vocally... he makes a terrible playable character, when you use your special ability you're basically rolling dice and the game tries to judge your situation for whichever vault hunter power to immitate. Unfortunately the game decided my situation required me to blow myself up 9 times out of 10. Yes I'm a bit salty about that. I don't use self destruction abilities in any video game really. So yeah, good times. It was fun hearing his cackling while I bounced on top of people, and it was nice not breathing air. Butttttt... I was a liability.   Style/Graphics/Appearance:  Borderlands doesn't try to aim for 'realism' in their game assets, instead they stylize their characters, models, and textures. This is very good in the long run, because it increases the longevity of the games appeal. You don't need to jump into the most recent game to enjoy the newest aesthetics, they start to average out over all their games. Don't get me wrong, there is a sign of improvement from game to game, but the style they use stays very uniformed rough and 'Borderlands-y'.   Price/value/game time played: Borderlands: The Pre-sequel is priced at $39.99, and the game with the season pass is priced at $69.99. If you're an achiever you will need to get the 'Holodome Onslaught' and 'Claptastic Voyage' DLC to earn 100%. At the time that I'm writing this review I've played 36 hours of Borderlands: The Presequel. That number will definitely change, there is still plenty to do, so you can definitely get your moneys worth out of game time.   Conclusion:  All in all, I've enjoyed what I've experienced with Borderlands: The Presequel, It's been most fun playing it with friends. I've enjoyed 'flying' around  (okay, it's not really flying, it's 'falling with style'.)  and as I so eloquently imaged it  'Mario Butt Pounding'  the NPC's. In a way the game feels shorter then it's predeccessor  (borderlands 2, man this 'pre-sequel nonsense is complicated, isn't it?) , so if you're looking for the best quality borderland games, this one doesn't have too much to offer outside of a couple new gimmicks and a few new playable characters. Story-wise, it's definitely worth it and very interesting! This game makes me want to own Jacks Hyperion Jacket.  (Why doesn't Borderlands have a clothing line?)  In conclusion, I'm not sure what to tell people, It's borderlands 2 ...in space! If you like borderlands, if you enjoy FPS, if you like the humor in the game series, you'll love this game just like borderlands 2.
Not the best borderlands, but its pretty neat

It's quite hard for me to give this game a just review.  I really enjoy the game, though I don't enjoy it as much as Borderlands 2, maybe after playing that for a couple hundred hours, the gameplay feels a little worn out.  I think that's because the game is almost identical to Borderlands 2, don't expect any revolutionary gameplay changes or a lot of new features.   It really feels like a big DLC, with a new story and new characters to play as. I don't like the characters (neither NPCs nor playable ones) as much as the ones from Borderlands 2, but then again, maybe that is because I played Borderlands 2 so much.  What I did like was the hole space and vacuum atmosphere, it's done quite well, you have low gravity and a ground stomp attack to use against enemies. Downside: You have to make sure your oxigen supply doesn't run out (unless you're Claptrap)  You got laser guns to go along with the space theme, which are kinda cool, too. Elements still work the same as in Borderlands 2, though there is no Slag - it has been replaced with Cryo weapons, which can be used to freeze enemies solid which then increases Melee damage, explosive damage and critical damage - not exactly like slag, but similar.  I'm not sure about the dialogues (your character talks now, too), but at least when playing Claptrap, it's pretty funny and the humor is definitely still there.  Though I didn't enjoy the game as much as Borderlands 2, I can't say that it's a bad game, so I'll definitely give it a thumbs up!

This game was a huge dissapointment. How anybody can rate this game in a positive light has never played a Borderlands game before and I would even go as far as saying has never played a game before. There are huge gaps in the story, random invisible walls, stupid mechanics, an extrememly small amount of bosses and unrewarding loot. Let me start with the loot. I played this game with 3 other friends and we all played a different class. We saw 3 legendaries, 1 of them being from a vendor and the latest drop was around level 21. We found ourselves being extremely overwhelmed with the enemies strictly because we had no loot drops. All the crates and loot thingys around Elpis contained commons and greens, sometime an epic or two. But most of all we found ourselves grinding out money to afford to buy a weapon or grenade mods to kill whatever we needed to kill at the time. Next up are all the glitches in the game. There are random invisible walls all over the world in spots where you have a clear line of sight to a ledge or a cliff that will just stop you and make you fall to your death; there are gaps in which you must jump over with your vehicle but even with a boost going top speed youd make it 50% of the time. The rest of the time youre falling helplessly into lava pits. Elevators will randomly glitch out and keep going up and kill you, bosses jetison loot out of their bodies when you kill them only to find yourself chasing the loot into a black abyss of nothingness, thus losing the loot forever. The characters are probably the most disappointing thing to me. Athena and Claptrap by far talk the most, and even then its not that much. Wilhelm and Nisha say next to nothing which is dissapointing because they are Jacks right hand people in Borderlands 2. They never address very important plots holes (I will not say in fear of spoiling it for people), and the end of the game seems extremely rushed. In total there are about 9 bosses. All of which are just point and shoot with no mechanics whatsoever. The typical comedy in the Borderlands series falls short in almost every avenue. The only redeming thing was Claptraps typical quips. Other than that, nothing. Cringe worthy material that is sure to make anyone feel dumb and awkward. There are pop culture references in the game that are just God awful. So awful to the point I almost ALT+F4'd out of the game. Having put in hundreds of hours in Borderlands on 360 and hundreds of hours on Borderlands 2 I can say I lvoe this series. With the exception of this. It is terribly short (we beat the entire series in 16 hours) and that was doing side quests and messing around at some times. The raid boss is just a harder version of the final boss. Overall this was a HUGE dissapointment and I will probably never load this game up again. I am very sad.

6/10 - This game feels a lot like just a big addon for BL2, which in and of itself wasn't that bad of a game. This game DOES add a lot of new things to the experience to freshen it up a bit. I feel like the game relies a bit too much on its sense of humor as a selling point. Honestly as a successor to the previous game, I felt as though this was a let down, let alone the price of it. Game play is still solid, shooter at its core. May revise this depending on how the DLCs that inevitably will come out do. All in all nothing too new here, didn't feel like it was worth 60 bucks.  EDIT: After having had a chance to more thuroughly play this game and feel it out, I'm revising my previous score of 6/10, I now give this game a 4/10. Between the amount of hindering glitches from the previous game they left in (mostly in the UI), the inclusion of new ones (mostly graphical that I've seen at this point), and the removal of some beneficial ones, it has become obvious to me that they made no honest attempts at playtesting this game outside of the already known bugs that gave us an 'unfair edge on the game', and giving little to no thought or care of the bugs that impeded us in the previous game (Ex: The UI bug in bl2 where it would jump to the opposite end of the list you are selecting if you attempted to interact with it too quickly). In addition to this, the AI feels the same in how annoying it was in bl2 where their pathing and movement was generally braindead until you got put into fight for your life, at which point every enemy within range would make a direct beeline for cover, sometimes as I've noticed, even clipping through walls and floors to do so, this made the combat feel tedious at times, and outright unfair at others. They also essentially remade the BNK3R fight from bl2 which I had a personal distaste for, if only because there were periods of anywhere from 2-5 minutes at a time where the boss would not even come into range of attack putting you in a deadlock of dealing with enemies and dodging mortar rounds from the boss that you could not hit. While they fixed not being able to hit the boss for this one, they made its attacks much more damaging, gave it more health from the looks, and threw in harder enemies to fight between phases, all of this is compounded with the fact that I found ammo to be scarce in this fight, constantly putting me in a position of buying ammo, or leaving the area to go find more. In general this game offers nothing new that is any good beyond laser weapons, zero gravity, and the cryo element which just feels like a slag that stuns. The story was a decent link between games however, but not enough to make up for its shortcomings.  EDIT 2: I feel as though I may have been too harsh with the review. All of these things I still hold to now, however I no longer feel as though they are as much of a detriment to the experience as I initially gave credit for. In all of it's shortcomings, it is still a Borderlands game. That being said, several changes and patches were made to this game to this point in time, a lot of these changes were bad, some were subsequently good to fix them, and public accounts from the devs were made that tweaked some members of the Borderlands community a certain way. Social media stuff aside, these changes IN THE END helped improve the game to a certain extent. With that in mind, what will likely be the final revision in my score is now 5/10. I still do not recommend it over BL2, but if you are looking for a fresh experience, provided you take it with a grain of salt, you may enjoy this game.

I don't think the game is really worth the current pricing. With a discount though, it's probably worth it. Here's why:     Poorly balanced, just as bad if not worse than Borderlands 2. I still play BL2, mostly because I have friends to play with, but nobody I play with thinks that getting downed in 2-4 hits feels fair. In BL:TPS this doesn't seem any different. The higher level you get, the stronger the issue seems to become, especially if you're having bad luck with loot drops, i.e. having less of a fighting chance.     Bosses are few in my opinion and they almost don't feel meaningful, even though they're supposed to have a major relevance in the story's development.  Bosses are also, again, poorly balanced. They often have minions that join the battle, presumably so you can get second winds if you go down, but they almost do the opposite because of their own individual power.  The last and before-last bosses atleast had some 'loot explosions' but I must have been extremely unlucky because most of it was junk, this despite the fact that I had really crappy equipment, many levels out-dated, which made me struggle to do the actual fights.     The story was good for the most part, but it feels rather short and the way the characters evolve is predictable (somewhat understandable) but I just think there could have been - a lot - more character development. Oh, right, and almost everyone that isn't a character of some importance has an australian accent, which seemed to get old a little fast for people who watched me play through.     Interface. Everything is the same as BL2, which isn't bad by itself, but the BL2 UI had some ergonomic issues -  such as the poor handling of the way the interface 'slants' and panels block each other  - and had a few glitches that haven't been fixed, like one that happens when scrolling through the backpack. In addition, the way Eridium is just translated into Moonstone is a bit unimaginative, as it serves the exact same purpose, and the story explanation doesn't feel good enough to me.     Of all the Borderlands games, this has to be one with the worst bugs. Mobs go THROUGH the floors, walls, ceilings, whatever! At certain parts of the game I had to start areas over because of this as they made completing certain sections impossible. I've read that even you, the player, can fall through the ground but I didn't experience this personally.     Sadly zones feel too big and vehicles aren't useable in several zones, and in the ones that they are useable in, they have limited areas you'll manage to use them in. Very few fast travel stations in my opinion, considering how annoying it is to trek around. My biggest issue with the size of the zones though, is that if for some reason I needed to quit the game while doing the story bits in the larger zones, I'd get sent back to a stupid point that was possibly quite far from where I stopped playing.   Overall the game was fun to play and the addition of the new element was 'cool' (replaces slag from BL2 though) and the grinder added a bit of variety to the way you can go about getting or upgrading gear, although it feels slow and cumbersome, due to the way you will pile up even more stuff than usual in your backpack. But in the end, it feels more like an expansion of sorts for BL2 than an actual new game, still having 'old' issues. In addition, the fact that the story content is kind of short makes all of the content in general feel kind of short to me, with all the side-missions being more or less equal to each other than they usually would be in the past. Perhaps things will get better with DLC.  I'd like to recommend a ' Yes ' for this, but I can't. Too many little things.
It's worth the cost on sale so I recommend that.   I found the whole experience overly Aussie and cringeworthy on too many occasions. The writing is the worst...

gameplay and mechanics in TPS are miles ahead of Borderlands 2 where it gets boring trekking back and forth over and over again, this is because of a more intuitive map/mission design overall where they tend to give you almost all the missions the first time around rather than sending you back xxx times to a zone miles away.  story is not quite as long but i prefer that as it's probably the right length to avoid it becoming a chore. story also feels less contrived to me, while still having it's weak moments, the setting feels a lot more involving. the game world is slightly more linear which leads to it feeling less like a free-roaming game - this would have been very easy to remedy imo.  the oxygen and jump boost mechanics are definitely a breath of freshly generated air, making travel on foot more efficient but also more enjoyable as it just gives that bit of extra freedom that allows better traversal of the often jagged landscape that is almost trademark to the Borderlands series. it is very rare for the oxygen mechanic to pose a problem as there are O2 generators everywhere, and when it does, i feel that it adds to the exhilaration, as you desperately sprint to find that precious O2 refill, while your health very slowly ticks down (when O2 is completely empty). i like how managing the jump boost and O2 becomes a balance, as you use O2 to boost and speed your travel whilst trying not to deplete your supplies too much until you see another refill point.  new hoverbike plays nicely, brings an alternative utility for a vehicle with it's ability to propel itself upwards for a few seconds. other traditional BL game mechanics such as storage deck upgrades take a more streamlined approach, mostly quality of life improvement to avoid players standing around wasting time for example at the slot machines. new lazer and cryo weapon types are both interesting and effective.  the heroes! they are just generally much cooler and more badass in TPS than BL2, and it's not just their look/characterisation, but also the special abilities which definitely pack more of a punch. overall this adds the feeling that they actually deserve their legendary reputations, unlike BL2 where it's more about SAYING how badass they are rather than just simply being badass.  by far the worst aspect of this game is the lack of good DLC, as the only real, fully-fleshed DLC is the Claptastic voyage, and while that has novel ideas and style to it, it starts to get dull before too long. this game desperately needs new DLC areas set elsewhere on the moon of Elpis, something i fear it will never receive now.

I like at least something about all the new characters. Athena, Nisha, Wilhelm, Claptrap and Jack (note: at time of writing the final dlc character hasn't been released) all have something going for them, be it tanking, damage or healing. The graphics are pretty timeless due to the nature of the engine and the soundtrack is up to the usual standards. Boss fights are generally fun and the storyline, presentation and dialogue is generally hilarious/appropriately serious but with a few misses. But yes, it does kinda feel like a glorified expansion.  To summarise, if you love the series, essential. If it's 'like' rather than 'love', you'll probably like it but it's not essential to your life. If you're not fussed about the series you probably won't be swayed. If you really hate the series, well, nothing will convert you, I don't think ;)

The Pre-Sequel is basically BL2 in space with cosmetic changes and additions.  The mechanics, AI, menu's all the background stuff are the same as BL2. Overall the game plays well, the main story is good if not a little short, the new laser weapons have good variety & the Vault hunters are brilliantly done. I would recommend the game, but would state that unless your big fan that wants to know the missing stories of the BL2 characters as well as have some Fragtrap induced lightshow seizure whilst taking on flying Australian midgets in space, I'd wait for a sale.  7.5/10

I just finished the Pre-Sequel after getting it in the Steam summer sale. After hearing mixed reviews upon release I decided to wait on it even though I loved the first two games. Now that I finished a single play through in 16 hours, I feel very happy overall about the purchase and wouldn't have minded paying full price, but I rarely do that for any game anymore.   Pros: - Cryo weapons (and the Baroness addition). I always liked Fire in the last two games, but Cryo is pure fun. Freeze and shatter! - Butt slam! This gets a bit difficult sometimes when you get jangled up on enemies, but the butt slam sure is entertaining. Early on I found the O2 issues annoying, but once I got used to it the long jumps and butt slams became much more fun than traditional running and jumping. - Story is great actually. Jacks back story and Athena getting some more story is awesome. Makes for a good sensible entertaining storyline.  - Grinder. Even if I rarely get anything I actually like ... grinder fun. He insults you while you grind. - Moxxi is still around being awesome. - Laser beam guns are badass.  Cons: - Pickle. Shut the f**k up! Seriously this character was too much for me. Meeethane. I'll give 2k and co. a pass because they've made soooo many great characters (Tiny Tina is the best, Jack, Moxxi, even Patricia Tannis is pretty hilarious), but he is still a negative to the game overall. - 1 Legendary item for sale the entire first playthrough. ONE. No legendary items from chests or bosses. I find that disappointing and a bit absurd. I don't expect tons, but a couple here and there? - Final boss guy. Didn't enjoy his over the top one shot me ability. The bigger version was okay, just took awhile, but the first part you fight was just annoying to me. - Sparse. What I mean is that I felt like half the time was spent running back and forth with minimal enemies. I want hordes of midget shotgunners and psychos! That is the most fun. - Pickle again.  Overall, I would definitely recommend this if you like the series at all. The first Borderlands is still by far my favorite, but 2 and the Pre-Sequel are both great follow ups.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is not as bad as what you think it is.  As a hardcore Borderlands fan, you'll be disappointed for sure but as a regular FPSRPG game, you will not be disappointed. Some good points that the game has and does better than Borderlands 1 & 2 is that the characters are more fun to play as and combat is more interesting as you have the ability to do double jumps and butt slams. For each character, you can come up with many different builds and that really helps up the replayability. Another good touch that the game has is that the character you play as actually responds to what the NPCs have to say.  However, as much as I like this game, there are still some glaring issues with the game that I would like to point out. One of the issues is that some of the missions just drag out for too long. This makes it very tedious for the player to go through and also makes it very repetitive. Speaking of repetitiveness, this game can get boring at times in my opinion. While I do believe that there is a good amount of replayability withtin the game, this game does not have as much replayability as Borderlands 2 as it suffers from the lack of end game content. In Borderlands 2, after you finish the campaign, you are able to farm these raid bosses for loot. In Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, however, there is only one raid boss to farm and that raid boss is the same as the final boss but just a more beefed-up version.  Overall, I do recommend this game as it is a lot of fun and you are sure to sink in tens and probably even hundreds of hours into the game.   FINAL RATING: 7/10

For all the hate and claims that this is just another BL2 I would tend to disagree and say this is a very fun game and can't wait for them to expand it out with the DLCs and various expansions. By not being a DLC for BL2 they are able to dump some of the mechanics that didn’t work and get a fresh start without high level characters just blowing through it all.  A lot of the haters talk about it being not as long at BL2 as though that’s a bad thing. I personally felt the main campaign in BL2 was too drawn out and made you do too much running around doing menial tasks to draw the story out. When people talk about how awesome BL2 was they are looking at Tiny Tinas or Torgues or scarlets DLCs. Just for reference I had all classes to 72 so I went through that painful storyline a LOT.   I felt TPS kept a better flow going and the missions weren’t stupid stuff meant to delay me. Having it be its own game let it dump some of mechanics from BL2 such as Slag which caused all of the higher bosses to be balanced around its use and instead replaced it with Cryo which freezes things solid.   The campaign is about the same length or a bit longer than BL1.  New weapon type in the Laser, there are a couple of different laser types, the beam type which gradually become harder to hold on target, the railguns which are sorta like a mid range sniper and laser shotguns which aren’t really much different from regular shotguns. Some of them can be useful but they aren’t earth shattering. The butt slam can be a lot of fun, I have buddies who will blast through areas just butt slamming everything that moves and giggling like little kids the whole time.   As for the classes they bring a different bag of tricks than the BL2 characters. There is no one character who is completely overpowered like there was in BL2 (I’m looking at you Salvador).  There seems to be a bit more attention on characters benefiting each other than there was in BL2. In BL2 there were only 6 skills that benefited teammates and like three times as many that a group oriented in TPS.  Very good game, and I look forward to what they come out with in the future DLCs

I totally love the Borderlands series, having invested over 600+ hours and counting in Borderlands 2. I love the artwork, humor, dialogue, quirky characters, and the GUNS. Borderlands 2 was one of the best games I've ever played and will always hold a special place in my heart.  However, this review is not on Borderlands 2, but on Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. Yes, it has incurred a ton of criticism for not being as large as Borderlands 2, falling short in places, and it retaining most of the gameplay features and mechanics from Borderlands 2. However, this was to be expected. Gearbox Software had repeatedly stated that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel would not be as large as Borderlands 2 and would be built off of it, being more of an 'extended' expansion pack. In addition, the development cycle for the Pre-Sequel was only 2 years, and it would certainly be tough to craft an entirely new game that would wow fans and blow them off their seats at E3.  Despite that, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel has some flaws that cannot be denied. (Let's go look at the cons first)  1) The unbelievable price tag.  Although this game is certainly good and it would be a great thing to support the devs, I feel like forking out $60 USD is definitely not worth the content. Even worse, if you wanted to grab the Season Pass with all the DLC, the price would be even higher. For a game that doesn't contain that much material and substance as Borderlands 2, I find that unacceptable. I bought the Pre-Sequel + The Season Pass bundle for around $25 and I find that a much better buy that is worth the money. $60 for a main game that lasts you barely 20+ hours (including completion of side missions and the main campaign) is not worth the buckaroos in my opinion.   2) The endgame. Borderlands 2 had a great endgame with far more replayability than the Pre-Sequel's endgame. In Borderlands 2, even after you've completed the side missions, you still had tons of stuff to do, bosses to farm, and loot to acquire. In the Pre-Sequel, I felt strangely lost and aimless after completing the main campaign and main side missions. There was not much left to do and I wasn't as motivated to go for multiple playthroughs.   With the cons out of the way, let's go into what makes this game stand out from Borderlands 2.  1) Player-characters. Let's face it. The Pre-Sequel has the best player-characters in the franchise. I had tons of fun experimenting with WIlhelm, Athena, and Nisha, and I've yet to play as the other 3 characters, which is something I look forward to doing. The difference between each character is noticeable and the playstyle you adopt varies with the character you choose. You can't play Wilhelm the way you play Nisha and vice versa. In addition, I love how some of the dialogue differs with the player-character you pick. It's a small touch, but I feel that it adds to the characterization and personality of each player-character, which was something missing from Borderlands 2. In Borderlands 2, I felt like a silent participant of events. Your character doesn't talk much and doesn't give any verbal responses to questions or happenings in the story; but in the Pre-Sequel, you get to see how each individual player-character responds in the same situation. One of the few reasons I went for multiple playthroughs was to experiment with the different playable characters and hear their unique dialogue.   2) Story. Although the story isn't the most intriguing and engaging one I've experienced as of yet, I felt that while it is shorter than Borderlands 2, it is better in certain aspects. While the story of Borderlands 2 was easy to craft since the Borderlands lore had plenty of area to explore and improvise on, linking the events of Borderlands 2 with another event is something different. I enjoyed seeing how the game portrayed a somewhat heroic and actually likable Jack slowly transforming into the villain he would eventually become in Borderlands 2. This game gives some background information to Borderlands 2 and once you've played this game, you can play Borderlands 2 from a new perspective and view Handsome Jack a little differently.   3) Added features. I personally loved the addition of lasers, the cyro element, and low-g environments since they added new depth to the game. Lasers are diverse and they are extremely fun to tinker with. The glitch weapons from the Claptastic DLC are also awesome and I would recommend getting that DLC or the Season Pass if you want the whole lot of DLCs and playable characters.   In conclusion, this reskinned Borderlands 2 has its flaws and upsides, and it does balance them out quite evenly. I wouldn't recommend buying this game at its current price of $60, but buy it during the summer or year-end sale and you'll get something worth your money. If the price is low enough, go ahead and the get the Season Pass too. Just as long as you're a fan of the Borderlands series and are not expected something similar to the scale of Borderlands 2, you won't regret obtaining this game.

Earlier, I wrote a rather lengthy review of Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel pointing out many of the different problems I had with the game up to a certain point. But after actually going through the main story on two of the characters, and after discovering a few handy shortcuts to speed up a game, I figured I'd re-write this review to give it a fairer assessment.  First, while I would recommend it to those who are already fans of the Borderlands series, I would strongly recommend Borderlands 2 as an entry point for a new player over this game.  The Pre-Sequel has some good things going for it. Interesting cast of characters, a plot that gives a new understanding (of sorts) to the backstory of Borderlands 2, a new low-gravity environment to survive in; these features make this game stand out from the others in this franchise.  Unfortunately, most of the main complaints I had before are still valid even after completing the main storyline. Most missions feel unnecessarily long, with you having to activate second and third backup plans jsut to get one thing done. Also, the terrain is littered with instant-death lava rivers that you are expected to jump over in a car (And yet can't do), some of the conversations seem forced and/or unnecessary, and while you have a new low-gravity playground to float around in, it's quite easy to get lost in unless you know where you're supposed to be going.  Again, if you've played one of the earlier Borderlands titles, I'd recommend this game to you, but for those who are looking for a place to start, you're better off going to Borderlands 2 instead.

Please not, that this is not the finished review for Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel! I'll update it once I played through TVHM with my thoughts on the endgame-content and the way TVHM works out.  The Story: I don't want to spoil anything, because pretty much everything that happens will work out in Borderlands 2. Basically, it's the story on how Jack became Handsome Jack, the villain in Borderlands 2. The side missions add cool additional insiders, such as the reason for Treshers living on Pandora. Everything is full of humor again and you'll meet loads of the characters you love from the second game of the series. The onliest thing, which I personally found a bit sad, is, that the villain this time (Zerpadon) is just a regular, evil, witch-like woman. No funny lines, no especial memorizable lines, just the normal villain you'll have in each and every game. It tooks me 22 hours to do each mission (both side-missions and story-missions) in Playthrough 1, the onliest quest, which is left, is the traditional raid-boss at the end, as I haven't found a team, which is able to beat him, yet, and can't solo him, due to a lack of skills.  The Classes: There're four playable characters again, without any of the DLCs. I'm playing Athena at the moment, so I can only say little about the other classes. Athena's special skill is her shield. She uses it to absorb damage and then throw it back at her enemies (up to four, if you got the right skill for it). The skill tree is equal in size and complexity to Borderlands 2, there's no overpowered skills or underpowered ones; as long as they fit your gaming-style, they're worth to go for. There's no relation between her and Borderlands 2. Wilhelm, the enforcerer, can summon two drones, which support him in combat. One supports his defensive skills and abilities, the other one actively fights enemies. You fight him in his final form in Borderlands 2 at around level 12-15. Nisha's a bit similar to the gunzerker in Borderlands 2, her special skill allows her to dual wield weapons. Sadly, this mode got an auto-aim this time, which makes it a bit less hard and challenging, else, the skill tree is focused on lawbringer-ish styles. She's the sheriff of Lynchwood in Borderlands 2, who you eventually fight in a side-quest. Claptrap... everyone should know him by now. He's the same annoying but funny robot as he always was. His special skill is a program called 'VaultHunter.exe' and allows him to scan the battlefield and use special-skills adapted to the situation. The skills include all classes available in Borderlands 2, and also the 'Gun-magician' and a pirate-ship. Yes, a pirate-ship. It fires cannons at your enemies.  The Gameplay: Of course, the main reason for playing game of the series is not enjoying the story. It's the quests, the loot, the gunplay. This can be summarized in only a few words. It's the EXACT same as it was in Borderlands 2, just with the difference, that you're in space now and there's no oxigen around most of the time. There's less gravity, making the overall experience feel a bit 'slower' than Borderlands 2. Also, you can double-jump now (which will use some of your oxigen) and smash down on enemies, which is quite useful and feels slightly overpowered with certain Oz-Kits. Those are a new item, which I'll go over in just a second.  The Items: The loot-system is the same as it is in Borderlands 2. I can't go over many legendaries by now, as I haven't found many. The ones I found were - as it seems - guaranteed drops by bosses, so nothing too special. A friend of mine had a double-legendary drop once, which was one guaranteed one and a random one. I THINK this wasn't possible in Borderlands 2, or at least I've never heard of it or seen anything like that. Correct me please, if that's wrong. There are a few new items:  First off, Laser-guns! These come in an interesting variety, all are classified as Laser-weapons, though. There're shotgun-like Laser-guns, SMG-like ones, and some, which have a kind of laserish fluent coming out of them, consuming ammo in specific amounts of time. Some of them feel overpowered, though, like the Zerpadon-one and the Moxxi-one. Secondly, there are Oz-kids now. You need oxygen in order to survive where's no oxygen, makes sense, huh? Also, it can be used to double jump and replaces the relics in Borderlands 2. Actually, it's like a relic, but with oxygen. The drop rates of greens, blues, purples and legendaries seem to be equal to Borderlands 2, at least to me, and in Playthrough 1 only by now (I spent around 300 hours in Borderlands 2, and it feels pretty much the same), however, I feel like whites are a bit more rare, especially in the later game. That's nice, though, as you won't pick them up except for reselling-purposes anyway.  The Difficulty: The game is easier than Borderlands 2. I didn't die at ANY boss, except for the final one, and I only died due to a lack of knowledge on how to fight him, as soon as I found out, I beat him at 'first new try'. I died like 30 times from groups of enemies, besides that I died like 20 times from jumping somewhere where I shouldn't, or getting thrown off the edge by enemies. That's not much for 22 hours of gaming, I remember having a way harder time in the first playthrough in Borderlands 2. I hope, the second playthrough gets a hell load harder. I liked it the challenging way. Oh, I can't solo the raid-boss at the end (I'm level 27 currently, got no legendary in use at the moment and have no super-duper planned build...) and have problems finding a group for him, which doesn't die all the time.  Summary: Overall, I think that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is more than just an AddOn to Borderlands 2. It's motivating, funny, will need at least 70 hours to be beat a 100% I suppose (according to my very own speed) and at least another 30 to farm for some legendaries and nice builds. And this on one character only. I guess it's fair to say, that, including the DLCs, which will come, you can have at least 200-300 hours of fun with this game, if you enjoy the Borderlands universe.

This is just a standalone add-on for Borderlands 2. The game mechanics are pretty much the same, but with new characters, new maps, new storyline, etc.  tl;dr: if you enjoyed BL2, you should like TPS as well. If you didn't - don't bother. If you haven't played BL2 at all, you should definitely check it out first. Even though I recommend TPS, I can see why it gets so much hate.  Pros: - fun gameplay - fun characters - fun enemies (NO MORE DAMN SURVEYORS) - fun story - fun low gravity physics, adds more variety to the gameplay - fun new cryo element - fun this - fun that - fun everything - just fun - main protagonists have much more dialogue compared to BL2 - it's cool to see Handsome Jack playing a pivotal role in the storyline, even more so than in BL2 - lengthy base game campaign - the ability to grind unwanted items is a welcome addition  Cons: - not enough DLC content (unlike BL2, you won't reach max level having played UVHM just once) - it might not live up to the expectations of many - too expensive (€70 for the base game + SP at the moment, w/o discounts) - some of the loot from BL2 is missing, most notably (for me) The Bee and Infinity, also no pearlescent items, and glitch weapons are overall less useful than seraph weapons/items from BL2 - just one raid boss, and a lame one at that (pretty much the same as the end boss) - hardware requirements are slightly higher compared to BL2, while the graphics (or anything else for that matter) doesn't seem to justify that - no overpower levels - there's pretty much nothing to do after you hit level 70  Overall - Borderlands 2 is cheaper, it has more content and it doesn't feel like a 2 years older game in any way; it's a much better value than TPS. If TPS had more DLCs and was cheaper, it would've been just as good as BL2, if not better. It's a shame that 2K Australia went bust and the plug was pulled way too soon. Why didn't Gearbox pick it up and continue development is beyond me.  Base game - recommended, Season Pass - arguably recommended, Shock Drop Slaughter Pit DLC (not included in the SP) - definitely not recommended (waste of money even with discounts).

There are two vehicles in the game, one is a reskin of the Runner from bl2, and the other is just the Manta from UT3. I have conflicted feelings about this game.   The first set of feelings are good, and this centers around some of the dialogue, the characters, and the storyline itself. There were times this game made me laugh uncontrollably, such as the basketball mission where the guy goes to make a slam dunk and breaks free of Elpis' gravitational pull while screaming 'BASKETBAAALLLLLLLLLLLLL!' I actually like most of the characters in the game, such as Springs. I was happy you met her during the beginning of the game because the first time you see her and her character intro really made me feel like this was going to be a good game. Also the story line was fantastic. I love storyline-based games to begin with, and BL:PS did a good job at connecting the events of BL1 and BL2, because that's what this game was supposed to be, right?   The second set of feelings I have are confused, upset, and a tad disappointed. The first thing I think of is the moon buggies and some of the level design. For example, Triton Flats, or even when you first get the buggy and you have to make a small jump over a pit of lava. I can't recall how many times I died, but it was absurd. As soon as I unlocked the Stingray, that was all I used so I could avoid getting aggravated. Who knows, maybe I'm just terrible at driving, but in BL2, I definitely wasn't.   I also didn't like some of the mission lines. It's one thing to have you traveling all over the map to pick up and complete past missions, but when you get a level 20 mission in an early level area, that just rubs me the wrong way, and the whole game was made like this. The only thing in BL2 that reminds me of this is the Cult Following missions, and that was my least favorite part of the whole game.   The last complaint I have about this game is who decided to look at the Borderlands and think, 'What if this game was a platformer?' Yeah, I understand that the game is based on the moon where there is no oxygen and low gravity; even praised the developers for how much thought they put into it by making incendiary weapons not work in the vacuum of space because there is no oxygen. I think that is brilliant and I also think that introducing a new mechanic was fun and throughtful, but I can't tell you how many times I haven't used the 'butt slam' in a fight, simply sticking with my guns/grenades.  TL;DR This game is great for Borderlands fans and fans of the storyline itself. The new mechanics are interesting and were  a nice change, but somewhat unmemorable for me in a combat sense. The platforming mechanic is disappointing because it almost takes away from from the FPSRPG Borderlands was originally.    Is this game bad? No, but it certainly is different.

After playing 7 hours as Wilhelm the enforcer at level 15, I have come up with the following list of Pros/Cons.  Cons:  -Fire weapons are next to useless since they don't work in no-atmosphere environments and 25% of the enemies you fight (Kraggons, which are like fire skags in space) are resistant to fire.  -not enough Mr. Torgue.  -You can kill really fast, and get killed really fast. For example, I was able to kill the second boss in one clip with my laser shotgun after killing his shield generators, but died one and got knocked down about 15 times.  -No exploding laser weapons.  -Grenades roll waaaaaay to far in low gravity, so rubberized grenades are the way to go.  -Zarpedon is a way less cool villain than Handsome Jack.  -All laser weapons have scopes for some reason, which is really annoying for laser shotguns.  -There are no psychos, despite being on the cover art of the game.  Pros:  -Story is intriguing  -Laser weapons are badass  -so are cryo weapons  -staus effect stacking seems to be back.  -You get your first skill point at level 3 instead of level 5  -You start with two guns, in my case a pistol and a shotgun.  -Intro is a lot more fast-paced and interesting than in BL2.  -Nice visuals.  -Your character actually speaks, though not very much, it's still funny.  -The grinder is a good idea, but I can't seem to combine blue or purple weapons.  -Money is actually somewhat useful, unlike in Borderlands 2, where all you did was buy ammo.  Suggestions  Modding/workshop support would be awesome  Day/Night cycle. Just because you are on the moon doesn't mean that whatever star lights up Pandora doesn't exist.

This post may become long. Readers be advised.  Borderlands 2 was the rage. With nearly three hundred hours on the record, it quickly became my personal favorite. I loved every bit of it - the design, the atmosphere, the witty-gritty humor, the characters and a really good, engaging plot for a shoot'n'loot game. Needless to say, I was super psyched with The Pre-Sequel as it was announced and it lasted until the day of release.  The beginning of the game made me feel like that again. Lots of action, witty dialogue, characters that seemed fun to play. And heck, we finally get to know Jack from his non-psychopatic side! That's what trailers promised. And for the first hour of the gameplay I was damn sure developers kept the word, making the game that would easily stand to previous titles of the series. But then you get to the moon, which you spend most of your game time on, and everything suddenly pops like a soap foam sphere.  First thing you notice - this game is aussie. The accents, the dialogue, even inside jokes. Compelling at first, quickly gets boring and irritating. At least for me, and I thought that I dig the regional humor. Turns out either I haven't really dug it or it is just poorly executed. Probably the latter. This is... Just not the same game. Moving on. Quests, both main storyline-related or sidequests, which varied a huge lot in Borderlands 2, here became either simple fetching, or simple killing, or combination of both, mostly involving also going a really long way across repetitive, uninteresting locations. Speaking of which - remember The Dust from BL2? The huge desert filled with quests and secrets like some kind of a sidequest pincushion? Here, on Elpis, you will get none of it. The game world is claustrophobically small compared to other games from the series.  The plot... See, Handsome Jack was one of the best written villains ever. It sounded rad - to finally see from behind his eyes, know his part of the story. What was done here is best described with two words: wasted potential. Also, it is really, really inconsequent in places. No spoilers, but... But it just is. There was not a single plot twist that would amaze me. Everything was... Predictable. I have expected something more. Something brilliant. What I've got is... generic at best. NPCs are not very memorable either. Nothing interesting about them, neither Nurse Nina nor that Springs chick, nor Meriff. Somehow, even the appearance, though episodic, of the old ones, like Mister Torgue, didn't manage to make me feel like that again. (Said Mister Torgue from overly masculine bag of muscle, which was the very core of this character being interesting, somehow became... a feminist white knight. Just what the hell... Though I admit it is good when games discuss important, current matters, the way it was done here just made me feel only disgust. It felt... flat, somehow.)  The game engine is buggy as a Thresher den. Characters get stuck in the landscape - a lot. The aim doesn't work properly, which is an issue in a game mostly built around shooting things. Speaking of shooting - new guns, lasers, cryo elements, suffocation. Sounds cool, but actually it didn't do much for the game's variability. If so, I've somehow felt it decreasing, in the end not really caring what guns I shoot.  New mechanics - low gravity, ground slams, oxygen supply. While fighting in low gravity, jumping, flying, jetpacking, slamming to the ground is really a good step forward and was done pretty well, adding some dynamics to stale combat, I think that whole oxygen mechanics is not very well executed. Instead of making the game more interesting, it became more of an irritating necessity to sometimes walk into rooms with atmosphere - on higher levels you don't really have to even do this, being able to suffocate for ten minutes and still somehow survive.  The new character mechanics is interesting, but truth be told - you won't have too much of an opportunity to use most of it. You've got Athena, which is female Zer0 with some tank capabilities, Wilhelm, who is Salvador-Axton crossover, Nisha, which is even more Salvador-esque and Claptrap who is completely unpredictable. Fun to play, but then again... The Developers gave you cool toys but no sandbox to play with them as much as you would want.  Other than that, there is not much variety to enemies you fight or stuff you do. There's not much to be done once the plot is over. I have managed to complete the game twice, once as Wilhelm, once as Jack the Doppelganger, but I really see no good reason to go for the second playthrough.  My verdict? 5+/10 at best, might add one point if you're as much a Borderlands nut as myself. And judging from what they did with Season Pass so far - I would rather dust off the good old Borderlands 2. It is just better in every aspect that this there Pre-Sequel.  I would also like to admit that I am terribly, terribly sad about how my most favourite series of all time has gone so much downhill. Not worth your money, my fellow player.  But then, that's my own two cents I am entitled to.

Do not buy this at full price, it is a shoddy Borderlands 2 DLC that feels short, empty and lacking.   My Problems with the game:  Guns: Fire weapons feel useless because most of the time you will be fighting in and out of oxygen zones meaning setting enemies on fire is hard and keeping them on fire is even harder which makes them feel far intherior to shock weapons. They removed slag and replaced it with cryo, cryo is decently fun don't get me wrong but it didn't feel like an addition so much as a lazy swap. Lazer weapons don't feel great to use personally because they lack impact and because of the way loot works, they often don't do a satisfying amount of damage either.  Characters: None of thier abilities had the same amount of fun that Borderlands 2 had, they reminded me of Borderlands 1. Not terrible, just vastly intherior to Borderland 2 and a little boring and this made upgrading them in the talent tree unappealing. I will say there is some fun to be had with using and upgrading Claptrap but that ability relies heavily on luck and can be equal parts frustrating as it is fun.  Areas: Anyone ever tell you how interesting and varied the moon is? No? Thats because it's not and this game does very little to change that. For most of the game you are going to be dealing with almost completely empty grey lunar landscapes broken up by grey factories with one area at the end which is vaguely interesting but nothing we have not seen a hundred times before in videogames.  Loot: Feels like you get very little loot and money, plus the loot that you do get is usually sub-standard gear that won't do a decent amount of damage. It seems like in order to get a gun that will do anything but slowly tickle your enemies to death, you need to buy one. Given the severe lack of funds in this game, it can be quite annoying.  Writing: The writing is hammy, cringy and has a clear adgenda. It feels like this game was written by an SJW who didn't know the meaning of subtlety.. All the good guys are suddenly gay or bisexual and feeling the need to tell you every 5 seconds which is wierd and straight people seem to only declare themselves as such if they are the badguys. Theres nothing wrong with being gay but it can be incredibly jarring when seemingly everyone wants to tell you about how totally gay they are, it shows the writers didn't write them as people but instead as 2 dimensional characters who's defining, and oddly popular, characteristic is thier sexual orientation. At one point Torgue turns up and goes full on feminist for seemingly no reason, it feels wierd, forced and incredibly cringy. Anthony Burch ruined the writing in this game by forcing his political opinions on the character and on the player.  Conclusion: I played this game with my girlfriend and on several occaisions we both wanted to put this thing down and give up. After pressing through the monotony and frustration we found that the game had very little to offer gameplay wise. The game is mercifully short however for some people this may be a negative as it represents significally less value for money. At a good discount this might be worth picking up for a borderlands fan, its alright but I didnt have as much fun as I did with borderlands 2 ... Just bare in mind that you may not get more than one playthrough out of your purchase.

I had high expectations for this game. I absolutely loved borderlands 2, and the characters, weapons, and gameplay physics of the pre-sequel seemed promising. I really wanted to enjoy this game, and I gave it the best chance I could, playing through with all of the characters.   I was disapointed by the sub-par story, poorly designed maps, tedious missions, limited enemy types, and forgettable characters. With the exception of lasers, the weapons are essentially a direct port from B2, and are no longer gratifying to find. Characters do not really unlock any game-changing skills until about level 25, so they do not really promote any unique playing styles.  All in all, I think it tarnishes the name of the Borderlands franchise, and I can't help but feel ripped off for paying full price. At best, you could say that this game plays through like a large DLC for Borderlands 2, but it dosen't have any of the appeal that Borderlands 2 had, and you definitely won't have the same ammount of replayability or endgame. If it were on a significant sale, I might reccommend buying it, but I can't really justify spending $60 for this game.

I think I chuckled at most maybe 3 times during the entire game (Which is about 18 hours long for a 100% playthru.) and 2 of those times were at Claptrap's expense.   The Vault Hunters themselves suffer numerous problems, first of which there is no specialization amongst them at all. In previous Borderlands there was a clear designation of who was the sniper, who was the support, but in the pre-sequel there is no sniper, instead everyone just has a couple sniper talents spread across their talent trees. Because of this you end up with a bunch of jack of all trades characters were none of them stand out in intresting ways. Their personality has alot to be desired as well, a fantastic example is Athena who stands out as being easily the worst character in the entire Borderlands series by virtue of being so incredibly boring, she could easily be a plank of wood with a face drawn on it and been a more exciting character. Nearly every line of her dialog reinforces the 'I'm a professional and only straight thinking in a crowd of loonies.' and god it gets old quick.   The returning NPC's stand out a bit better, though nowhere near as good as they are in previous games, some of the new NPCs like the Nurse fall completely flat. Overall in terms of mechanics its basically verbatim of 2 just with a annoying oxygen gauge that you constantly have to babysit or you slowly die while your sound is muted. The addition of laser guns is honestly forgetable, they don't really serve a niche in comparison to the already existing types of firearms and you'll just forget they exist mostly. It also still suffers from the exact same problems in Multiplayer were there is only shared loot with no roll system, enemies becomes instant kill with single shots and outragous bullet sponges if you in a group with more then 2 people. The game is created with the Borderlands 2 engine, so yes, it looks a lot like Borderlands 2 to begin with. But that can be a good thing.  For those unfamiliar with the Borderlands series, they're games all about FPS shooting and random loot drops for weapons, shields, etc. The Pre Sequel is similar, but includes new random weapons and special kits.   You get four new characters to play as, each with different special abilities. The characters all have three skill trees which improve multiple aspects.   The story takes place between Borderlands 1 and 2, and the main questline is pretty interesting. The dialouge is well written in most cases. The game can sometimes feel like a grind, but that's just how it is.  The enviroments are varied, and mainly take place on a moon. This means you can take extra big jumps, do ground slams, and run out of air to breathe. It puts a new spin on the combat. Certain enemies can seem a little too similar to Borderlands 2's enemies at times, but this can be overlooked.  Since this was done on Borderlands 2's engine with minor tweaks, the graphics are pretty much the same, although the Pre Sequel runs better on the same settings as Borderlands 2 on my laptop. The cel shaded look is unique, but that takes out pretty much all realism, which isn't a bad thing.   All in all, it's a great game. Some may argue it's just a cash grab and would be better suited as DLC, but I strongly disagree. The game has a ton of content and replay value. If you're not worn out from playing Borderlands 2, then this game is for you. If you're a fan of RPGs or FPS games, this game is for you. Even if you're a first time player, you can get into the game pretty easily without knowing the story from the other games in the series, although I recommend playing the games in order. My rating? 8.5-9.  Oh, and as of writing, I've put around 2 hours in the game, but only on Steam. I've spent a lot more time playing it on Xlive.

Basically, I got what I expected. It's not a bad game, it's better than the first, but dear god. . . .just, the second was SOOOO much better.   Okay, remember Borderlands, bare bones of an awesome game? Yeah you do. And then Borderlands 2 came around and fixed everything, literally, everything. New UI, Added a real story, Better and more VAs, Better classes, Better loot, More random loot, More guns, More playstyles, More Guns, and enough DLC to turn the base, somewhat simplistic game (that was still awesome) into a truly epic wonderland.  Not only was BL2 epic, but it was such an enormous improvement over the first, but I didn't expect that for this, and neither should anyone.  In fact, this is as step backwards, in every way. If BL2 was two steps forward, this is one step back.   The maps are redundant, too-large for their emptiness, and worse than having every area look more or less the same? You WILL re-trek each area, repeatedly, for no reason, far in excess of what BL2 did. The worst aspects of the side quests in BL2, particularly the 'Go do this! Heyy . . .wait. . .can't do that, okay, so run to the opposite end of the map, do this, oh wait, can't do this, go ahead and run back now, do this third thing. Good, now go do the second, and then run all the way back to do the first thing that shoulda been the only damned thing!'   I don't mind a little padding, but almost half this game is padding. . . .And I love me some filler, but. . . the character just aren't 'there' in this one. I don't have a problem with the Aussie thing, dunno why so many do really (it was made there, and why do people seem to hate Aussies anyhow?) -- I don't get all the jokes, but most of them just fine. I dunno what a billabong is tho :P. Anywa, the filler is just lacking, and a lot of that falls on the characters just not having the appeal of BL2 . .. but c'mon, the whole joke with Hammerlock is that he is, polite. . . .and he's one of my favourite characters. I'm not asking for complexity here, and I think it is the setting that ruins everything. The moon was jsut a really, really, REALLY bad setting.  What's really irksome, is that I cannot imagine it really saved them that much money in the end to have a million moon areas that look identical rather than having a few terrains like BL2 had done, desert, ice, grassland, city, eiridium blight, canyon, city, another city (but totally different), Hyperion Base, Animal habitat (savanna?) -- and then DLc which each had their own distinct character.  I didn't even know where I was 80% of the time in this one because. . .it's all the damn same. Moon. Moon. Moon. Moon. Infuriating space-station open-space area, Moon, Space station, Moon, Space station, Moon, Moon, Vault.  The moon was an AWFUL idea.  So, if you haven't, go play BL2, then BL1, then this if BL3 ain't out yet.  I'll update if the DLC quest expansions justify additional info.

The brand new setting - Elpis, Pandora's moon - is full of varying enemies, environments, and of course, loot. There are many new bosses, each with their own hilarious dialogue. Summary: Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel beautifully portrays the talent of 2K Games, flaunting breathtaking landscapes, challenging boss fights, and powerful butt-slams.
