Rating: 7/10 -  Is the game good? Yes. Worth $60? Probably not... But its still a very fun experience. Good but not great so far, and I will rewrite my impressions when I am done.  The game is pretty much more of the same as far as Borderlands is concerned which is NOT a bad thing. Several aspects of the game feel weaker than the previous main installment, but the new elements such as the low gravity and slamming are fun and don't ever get boring.  The Good: Borderlands the Pre Sequel pretty much keeps the gameplay of the previous installments, which has always been entertaining, if not particularly groundbreaking. The new gravity and jumping mechaincs are fun from the start and stay entertaining throughout. Collecting ridiculous amounts of loot is still a blast, and the new environments are quite pretty. While some say the game's humor is very weak, I'd say its still strong, just very much diluted - Borderlands 2 had every mission as hilarious as possible, while the Pre-Sequel has a lot fewer outright funny quests and characters. This is, in my opinion, completly covered for with the frequently hilarious vault hunter dialogue, especially from Claptrap. Speaking of which, the vault hunters are a lot of fun both in terms of gameplay and humorous quips (except for Athena... she can be a bit boring). Finally, the story chronicalling the rise of the much loved/hated villian from Borderlands 2, Handsome Jack is so far solid and very entertaining. A few moments do fall flat, though.  The Okay: The new laser weapons are nothing spectacular - it feels like it fits in the series and they have their own 'feel', but they are not particularly spectacular. I feel similar about the loot - it fits with the series, but nothing spectacular. A higher number of 'exciting' loot drops would be very much appreciated. Also, combat seems rather inconsistant - some fights are relentless and brutal, filled with badasses and varied dangers (seriously, it feels like there are more badasses in some of the earlier missions than in the entirety of a run through Borderlands 2...), but other fights are quick and feel empty even when similarly leveled to the player. The Scav enemies are basically bandit analogues, and feel very similar to those in the previous game. Most quests are mechanically uninspired as well, being simple 'go to x, kill y' affairs. Though, since this was very much the MO for the previous games, I don't know what people were expecting...  The Bad: This game does drag at many points, and the lack of humor in some parts leads to stretches of the game that can be a bit of a chore to complete. In additon, some of the new characters are rather lame, and retcons to some characters feels done just for the sake of doing it rather than for any particularly good payoff - but that might change when I finish the game. Oh, and the timed quests are still annoying as ever, often requring you to go through an clear areas once (failing the quest because you took too much time) to have any shot at doing it on the second try. Doing them single player can be quite difficult in a frustrating way. Try not to play SP by the way if you can help it - the best aspects of the game (the vault hunters and fast paced combat) shine brightest with friends, while the worst aspects (the long boringish sections, and the unintersting missions) are exponentially more annoying solo. If you do not want to play multiplayer, consider my review a 6/10 rather than a 7/10.  The Ugly: The moon buggy can take a leap off the cliff, which is all it seems to be good for. You get another vehicle around level 10 or 11, and it is so much better it isnt even funny. The weapons for the moon buggy are fun though.  In summarry, a good but not great entry in the series. While it is more than an expansion pack, it isnt up to the standard of the previous game or its better DLCs (Tiny Tina's), but it is still a lot of fun and is more than a cash grab by 2k. Anyway, have fun on Elpis, Vault Hunters!

For $60.00 this is what I expected:  1. pre-existing BL2 issues and bugs Fixed. The only issue patched was the only thing useful in BL2. Bring back duping because not all of us have the luxury of farming for gear and moonstones for hours on end, and it's often the only way to remedy a hostile loot system.  2. 95% bug-free on release. This WIP is currently at 95% annoying, bug-filled.  3. It's already been established that gamers do NOT like Distance Running Simulators. Go work on Arma or Day-z if you like making endless running games. in other words, where the hell are all the Fast Travel nodes or Amped Jump pads that can catapult us accross a level, especially at quest turn-in?  4. I don't expect to purchace an Expansion/DLC as a full content, full priced game. This will be my first and last time pre-purchasing a game EVER.  5. Companies should own up to the WIP they release as completed work and give their loyal users a meaningful apology by way of monetary credits or AMAZING & USEFUL in-game rewards.  6. Had I been new to Borderlands, the first few quests requiring jumping the gaps with a Zoomy and dying over and over would have turned me off completely -- RAGE QUIT & UNINSTALL, turned off. Jumping vehicles via ramps should not require cartesian equation or machine-like timing.  7. A fully implemented and functional LOOKING FOR RAID or LFG function would have been nice. In fact, a much improved Match Browser and Stable Net Code is desparately needed.   What I received for $60.00:  1. Having completed the first playthrough, I can state that TPS felt like DLC. The Objective markers have been rendered nearly useless and difficult to follow especially in large maps or when target objectives are in unorthodox places. Running back and forth to complete quests gets OLD -- give us some Amped Jump pads or vehicle ramps to catapult us free of tedium.  4. Losing loot to clipping issues or Bad Asses' taking their orange loot off a cliff with them following a satisfying butt-slam is extremely disheartening.  5. Zoomy Ramp jumping should not be a source of frustration and endless deaths, especially at the start zone with the potential of forcing a RAGE QUIT & PERMANENT UNISTALL.  6. Issue preventing many of us from posting any Steam Reviews about TPS was just coincidental, right? 'You must wait until this product has been released before writing a review for it' the message read, preventing me from posting my DO NOT recommend review. Maybe the sales quota hadn't been reached yet and they didn't want any prospecive buyers disuaded just yet -- hmmm.

Very very late review, but I still want to give it a review! Okay, so I'm going to be completely honest - no, this game is not as good as Borderlands 2 but it's a pretty DAMN GOOD GAME. The story is fantastic, setting and atomsphere I personally adore and the Aussie accents are really funny! :)  The story and amount of weapons doesn't even compare to Borderlands 2 and let's not even talk about the DLC cashgrabs. Borderlands 2 puts this game to shame regarding story and such, but I've beaten it three times and I really enjoyed every single minute of it. If you're thinking about getting this on a sale, do it, you will not be dissappointed! This, I would say, is a great 'in the meanwhile' for us who are waiting for Borderlands 3 :D

While the game itself is quite fun, it lacks in the memoribility of the previous titles.  Most enemies are just retextured versions of Borderlands 1 and 2 enemies with different names and the same combat styles with slight variations. The story, at least to me, seemed rather short and uninformative compared to 2. You do get some decent information on Jack's rise to power and his actions in the second game... but you also miss out on vast amounts of possible info as well that simply wasn't added.  Gameplay is identical to the previous games with the added element of needing oxygen and a low gravity environment. Control in low gravity areas (which is almost everywhere) is fairly easy and I believe they did that well. The need for oxygen is rather annoying if you are someone who would like to explore or boost everywhere. One of the higher capacity oxygen masks that I found was about 170 capacity. Each full boost takes down 10 of that.... so you will quickly deplete your supplies if you want to move around quickly in the somewhat barren areas.  Going through the first playthrough was fairly entertaining and only slightly challenging, as it should be. The second playthrough is just difficult and unforgiving. Enemies are constantly 2-5 levels higher then you and you progress and nearly everything can 1 shot you without warning. In many cases the badass variants of enemies can be harder then the bosses of the area you are in. You will be required to farm xp and weapons quite often if you don't want to get constantly slaughtered in every area.  The NPCs are all rather limited with dialogue and quests. There are several good side quests, but most are very generic. The rewards from them tend to be average as far as usefullness goes... but some are just pointless.  While the previous titles contained a lot of humor that was easy to understand, the Pre-Sequel seems to have little to no humor without first researching what it is they are trying to make humorous. I did find a few rather amusing parts, but they weren't as memorable and laugh inducing as the ones in the previous game.  As others had mentioned, glitches and bugs are quite a problem... depending on what happens. I have been killed by nothing, been shot at through walls, and even been the victim of rocks/platforms that aren't really there. I have also been blessed to have a never depleting shield, one shotted some enemies that I know I shouldn't of been able to, and had enemies be motionless while I unloaded on them. It definately needs to fixing.  One more small annoyance I had... Bosses, in the second game, were a primary source of farming for legendary weapons and items. In this one, many of the bosses are one time only fights with no chance to farm them. There are still several bosses that can be farmed, but not many effective ones.  Now for some good things.  There seem to be more chests around then in the second game which in beneficial to loot farming. Getting to the few farmable bosses is a fair bit easier then on 2 as well. Farming said bosses can be challenging, but manageable when properly leveled.  The Vault Hunters' skills are all rather unique and can be quite effective in solo or multi situations. From Claptrap's randomness to Nisha's autotargeting, they all make for very unique characters.  Plenty of sidequests to do and a few easter eggs to find make it quite similar to Borderlands 2 in that aspect. It can be quite entertaining to find whole quests that are just easter eggs as well. :)   I suppose, overall, it is a good game in need of some work. Hopefully any future DLCs and updates will remedy most of it's current problems and make playing it a more enjoyable experience. I think, as it stands, I would give it roughly a 7.5/10.  I do like the game, it just needs work. But I would only recommend getting it after a bit of a discount as it currently is. Unless they fix some issues first.

A below average game, terrible design decisions, boring story, shallow characters, frustrating gameplay.  Now before I continue, I am not comparing it to previous sequels which mostly carried over similar issue.  My biggest problem with this game is how it is designed. You can't lose in this game, every time you die you are respawned at near checkpoint. If you were fighting a boss and died in the middle of the fight, that boss is going to be at whatever hp it was when you died. You can't restart the fight from the beginning. It absolutely ruins any challenge and any sense of accomplishment. When I battle a boss I want to go toe-to-toe an beat it in one setting from 100% to 0, and not run back chirping away at his healthbar on every death. And if he beats me, fine, but I want to try again from the beginning.  On top of it game is hard. You will die a lot at least in the beginning. Some enemies have elemental damage which pretty much kills you in one hit. So a lot of it is reduced to: kill 5 guys, die, respawn, kill next 5, die, respawn, etc...  The story is absolutely a drag. Even Jack who was a blast in BL2 and supposed to be the most interesting character is reduced to a bunch of pointless one liners like 'go here' and 'do that' with occasional unfunny joke here and there. Other NPCs are even worse, completely unmemorable, and MMO-level bland 'quest-givers'.  Game does not introduce anything new. Laser weapons and limited oxygen could have just been a small expansion. And one of your main features is buttstomp, you know your game sucks.  Worst of all this game is just boring. Save your money.

Comedy is the glue that binds a Borderlands game together. Instead of smirking at a witty reference, I'm cringing a clumsy one, or a joke that makes no sense in the esablished context.  I also have some issues with the pacing, lack of diversity in enemies, fast travel locations, and other aspects of this game, but they're easy to overlook for me - the uninteresting writing is not.

Borderlands the Pre-Sequel: a great addition to the Borderlands series. After beating the game, I discovered how much fun I had exploring, fighting, and looting my way through Elpis, the moon that the story takes place on. As usual in the Borderlands series, there were halarious characters and exciting easter eggs to be discovered. The main plot is about 4 mercanaries named Athena the Gladiator, Wilhelm the Enforcer, Nisha the Lawbringer, and Claptrap as the Fragtrap. All with unique personalites, each character that you can play as took a job by the contractor of Handsome Jack, a Hyperion worker who is significant in the storyline of Borderlands. Although Borderlands the Pre-Sequel's graphics were about the same as Borderlands 2, I did not find it bothersome, and the colors in the worlds I traveled in were rich and pleasing. New weapons, including cryo weapons (ice-like element) and laser weapons, were fun to use. Adding the 'zero-G' factor into the game really added a twist into the combat of original Borderland titles. One unique element of zero-G is the butt slam, a jump-crouch-slam technique that can throw off enemies allowing time to heal or recover from something. Multiple vehicles can be driven in the Pre-Sequel, including the standard buggy, now know as the moon buggy, and the Stingray which is a floating vehicle that also can butt slam in its own way. The story line was filled with infamous boss fights and daring challenges that kept me, the player, really wanting to keep going and strive for the best loot and inevitably completing the game. Here is the summary described as pros and cons:  Pros: 1. fun loot 2. great sories 3. new characters that add a funny yet satisfying addition into the game 4. epic boss fights 5. Zero-G (duh) and the butt-slam 6. rich color schemes 7. The Grinder, a new machine to combine weapons to make new ones!  Cons:  1. Anyone who hasn't played a Borderlands game in the might feel lost in the story line 2. side missions led you to the same places, and I wish they added a few more places to explore 3. graphics were about the same, but it did not bother me 4. a little more heads/skins for characters, but that can easily be added in  Overall, I did NOT feel that the game was rushed, like some people may say. A great 3rd game into the Borderlands series. I think they did a great job with the story and missions to experience and explore. Rating: 9.6/10 People New to Borderlands: 7.9/10

A game with mediocre characters barely worth remembering and humor as dry as the desert from the country it is based on, the story and gameplay are all that drives this game forward. Despite what many have said, the story in the Pre-Sequel is suprisingly enjoyable. Sure, it wasn't the best one they have done, but it was nevertheless engaging and enjoyable to follow. The sidequests were, on the other hand, unfortunatly barely worth doing and very few come to mind that were humourous, creative, and original. Thankfully, there are some special weapons that are rewarded from some quests that make them doing worth while. Shame that was my only motivation doing them.  The gameplay was, suprisingly, a thrill to play. Introducing lazers, a Zero Gravity Enviorment, and butt slams, this addition to the series was highly enjoyable. I found myself as a lazer-based class (Wilhelm) while buttslamming scavs from 50 meters in the air, and I enjoyed it quite a bit to say the least. Also, the option to use the Grinder, a machine that can combine items into something better, was a neat little addition to the game. A big downside, however, was the character skills. It felt rushed, unexciting, and focused more of co-op gameplay mechanics (E.g, Claptrap.) Not that I have a problem with co-op skills, it just felt punishing towards players who focus on Solo games rather than the Multiplayer, despite the fact that the franchise was largely known for it's drop in, drop out co-op. Borderlands 2 was fun for both Solo AND Multiplayer characters, and that is what I enjoyed most about it. Another downside was lack of respawnable bosses, which dimminishes the game's replay value with a single character. But I have spoken too long on the gameplay, so lets go right to the story.  The story, although stale at first, shines as being one of the more interesting stories in the Borderlands series. Regardless if you thought that Borderlands 2 was 10x better than the Pre-Sequel's, it was nonetheless enjoyable for me. It drove me to keep playing to see what will happen during the next mission. I wanted to see Jack go from Zero to Anti-hero. It was great, and the main protagonist dialogue was a treat as well, especially Claptrap's lines. As I stated in my first paragraph, the sidequests were forgettable and mediocre, which is disappointing for a Borderlands game. The humor gave me the occasional chuckle, and the rare 'LMAO' moment, while the rest were either unfunny, 'meh,' or even cringe-worthy. That is a big turn off from a series built on it's humor and clever dialogue.  The DLC is probably the biggest turn off of the series, and here's why;  The studio had it's plug pulled after the negative responses from gamers and critics alike over the game. Which is a damn shame, since the Claptastic Voyage was a gem to play, rivaling that of Tiny Tina's Raid on Dragon's Keep from Borderlands 2. If they had kept going and had more time to extend the life of the game, maybe, just maybe, they would have redeemed the game. At least the studio, despite their game being hailed as the most disappointing installment, went out strong, and I commend them for that. Sure, the rest of the DLC is 'meh' compared to Borderlands 2, but it is still worth checking out, along with the two Vault Hunter DLCs.  OVERALL:  If you wish to play a Borderlands game filled with mediocre humor, innovative gameplay, fun story but forgetable characters and sidequests, then this game will satisfy you until the next installment comes out. You may not spend as much time on this game as you did in Borderlands 2, but it will occupy you for a good 30-40 hours depending on your pacing ingame. I'd get this game on sale or at ♥♥♥'s website. Other than that, i'd wait until then.  Rating: 7/10, a game that lacks from the previous installment yet is enjoyable nonetheless.

Let's get one thing perfectly clear here. This game isn't a real sequel. It's a standalone dlc, or a spinoff. Like Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon. It was made to give people who wanted more, even crazier borderlands 2, more borderlands 2. That means: the game is even crazier than the original but not as big or long, just like Blood Dragon was. The core gameplay is way more fun than bl2, the weapon system has better guns and doesn't make you save edit to get weapons that are actually useful. The movement system is wonderful. I've had about as much fun with this game than I did the entirety of bl2. It's priced the same, sure, and that's the game's biggest downfall, but as far as I'm concerned this 'pre sequel' is a spinoff that's made to be enjoyed alongside borderlands 2. The whole fact that the moon and helios was staring at you point blank in the face the entirety of bl2 really proves my point here. This was made for people that wanted a crazier borderlands 2 experience, and as far as I'm concerned, this game is worth the money for that alone.  There are a few drawbacks to this: 1. don't expect as much content or filler 2. the gameplay is way more fun, and the guns a better mixture of the fairness of bl1 and the coolness of bl2, but the environments and the game's length isn't as long. 3. People who wanted a true sequel were misled and as such this game may force people to give up on the franchise when really that wasn't the point of this game.  So in the end, is it worth it? Only time will tell. The fact is, at the current price, this game really deserves more dlc content. My reccommendation is, if you are on the edge, wait for a sale. The people who are playing it currently are the intended audience, fans of borderlands 2 that wanted more from what the game currently had to offer. Like Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon, or perhaps 4 with less content.  The main story takes around 17 hours to complete. Borderlands 2's was 34 hours. My point has been said.

Borderlands has always been a really huge favourite of mine. Borderlands 1 was amazing, and Borderlands 2 was sublime. In the end I'll always think of the series as worth the hundreds of hours I spend on each one. However I do have to say that The Pre-Sequel does seem the worst of the trio. Borderlands 2 had literally days of content before the end, and almost more post game content even if you didn't buy a single DLC mission. Pre-Sequel is about half the length to get to the end even if you take your time and complete every mission, and with even less endgame stuff to enjoy after it's all finished. Also the enemies are kinda bland in this game, Borderlands 2 had an amazing repetoir of enemies to fight, from the lean and lanky psychos, to the heavilly armored and bulky marauders, the half mechinized Hyperion engineers, the shirtless badass bruisers or the hunched and hopping ratmen, and that's before you get to the non-humanoids. Pre-Sequel kinda has all the humanoid enemies all wearing the same black spacesuit, you can barely tell them apart until you read their nametags. And there are only 2 different non-humanoid enemies in the entire game.  But is it good? Is it worth it? Oh god yes. Even if it is 'more of the same' it's more of the same in the best way. You still have the amazing plot writing, the extremely fun running and moving, the bazilion weapons to collect and use which all feel drastically different to wield, and of course the versatility to create your own playstyle.  New in the pre-sequel include a whole new weapon type, or types rather considering that the new Lazer weapons are so varied in how they shoot that they're barely comparable. And the dropping of the overcentralizing Slag element in favour of the new Cryo element which seems nether overpowered like slag was in BL2, or useless like Corossive was in BL1. It gives a serious damage amp to your shots just like the aformentioned ones, but only to certain shot types, giving serious power to what would have been weaker normally. And the dropping of underwhelming relics in favour of fun jetpack-like Oz kits which let you do extra attacks and doublejump, speeding up your traveling across the map considerably. The new vault hunters are also very new with their own unique playstyle and skills to use, many of which are unlike anything which has come before.  I am going to sink loads more hours into BL;TPS before I do eventually go back to BL2, that's for certain.  Also you get to play as Claptrap... which is pretty neat.

This is an absolute must have for any Borderlands fan. The Pre-Sequel is aptly named as it isn't quite a true sequel to Borderlands 2; the game's mechanics, graphics, and even items to some extent are all the same from Borderlands 2. However, for someone who loved the second game, this is the perfect continuation of the Borderlands we know and love, and has plenty of new features and content to keep you entertained. The classes are characters this time around are a real step up, with much more interesting skills, skill trees, dialogue, and costumes. The storyline is even better than BL2, and all of the bosses are crazy, colorful, and a ton of fun to fight. Despite some returning items, much of the loot is brand new, and the new lazer and cryo weapons are awesome to play with. The vehicles have also been given an upgrade, as the Moon Buggies feature much more powerful armaments than the vehicles of BL2, and the new Stingray is a blast to fly around in. As of right now, the only real con to the game is the fact that some of the bosses do not respawn, and are therefore non refarmable, however, Gearbox and 2K have already said they recognize the problem and are looking into a fix for it. Beyond that, the endgame does feel a bit empty, but this is customary of Borderlands pre DLC, and what with Gearbox's reputation and track record for incredible DLC, I am sure this is a situation that will be speedily rectified. In all, this is an incredibly fun game, either alone or with friends. Veterans and fans of the Borderlands series will love this 'Borderlands 2 2.0', and for players new to the series, this is the perfect place to jump in and start exploring the rich world of the Borderlands universe.

That being said, this game is very well-done and all you would expect from a Borderlands game. The humor is there, the plot gives GREAT backstory to Borderlands 2, and of course, there are billions and zillions of guns to check out. Sure, it might not have been as big or as good as Borderlands 2, but it is still an extremely fun and game well worth your money. $60 might be a bit much, but if it's on sale for $40 or even $30, definitely pick it up if you enjoyed Borderlands 1 and 2.   If you do buy the game, do NOT buy the Season Pass. The Season pass does not seem to be worth it; as unlike Borderlands 1 and 2, which included 4 Storyline DLC, Borderlands Pre-Sequel Season Pass includes character DLC and the level-upgrade pack, so just buy the Story DLC separately when it comes out.

Explosions, laser guns, space bandits and more all-around Borderlands fun! What's there not to like about Borderlands: TPS? Well, that depends on what your expectations are. I've finished the story and am about halfway through the TVHM mode. It has been a fun ride for the most part. That's not to say that there aren't snags in the game.  Lets start with the positives first.   WEAPONS: Laser weapons are generally fun, yet also feel somewhat underpowered. Some of the classics from Borderlands 2 return in some form or another. There is also a new addition to the game; The Grinder. Once you unlock this fine machine, you can feed it weapons/items that you don't want and in return, receive another weapon or item. It takes a little experimenting to get right but there is no guarantee that you will get something awesome.  THE WORLD: No more Pandora this time around. Now you are on the moon of Pandora, Elpis. I found Elpis a pretty fun place to cause mayhem in. It is also very colorful and varied for being a moon. Lord knows that this aspect could have been royally screwed but I feel that 2K Australia got it right. It's not as big as Borderlands 2 but is still a nice size and you could get lost here.  THE GAMEPLAY: If you've played a Borderlands game before this, then you know what you are getting into here. The gameplay is smooth, controls are responsive and it all comes together to make for a great experience. There are a few new aspects however. This being a moon, there is very little gravity and this was taken into account. You can now double jump, butt-slam and low-gravity just gives fights all new dimensions. Butt-slams are awesome and really helpful when you are surrounded by enemies.  VEHICLES: This is sort of a mixed bag. Vehicles are present in two forms; moon-buggy and some sort of hoverbike type of vehicle. The handling is the same as Borderlands 2. I can't complain about that but I know that a lot of people didn't like that. Genrally fun and good for long distances.  AI and ENEMIES: The AI is pretty much at the same level as Borderlands 2; sometimes it's challenging and sometimes dumb as rocks. The enemy variety could be better but I was satisfied with what was presented. I miss the bandits from Pandora; nobody wanted me to be their meat puppet.  Now for the bad:  The story is kind of short. Whereas Borderlands 2 was 17 chapters, this only has about 12 or 13, some of which are over in a breeze. It's also not quite as interesting as Borderlands 2. Some of the humor is also lost on people not familiar with Aussie humor. I missed that from Borderlands 2.  The world is not the biggest out there. It feels like they could have added a couple more areas to explore. Borderlands 2 was humongous and absolutely filled with side-quests but this is just not the case here. What's there is nice but it could have been larger.  To little side-quests fill Elpis. There are many sidequests but it feels like there could have been more and there are some parts of Elpis that just could benefit from something to do. Don't get me wrong, you should always quests to do but not in the quantity of Borderlands 2.  The last part is dedicated to the overpriced dlc. Ten Euros/Dollars for Handsome Jack!? Ten Euros/Dollars for one single arena that is being panned by everybody!? What were you thinking 2K? That's just too much and those that spent money on the season pass got royally screwed because those count as two of four items. I hope that the next two are worth it and better.  Overall, I'd give TPS a 7.5/10 and can recommend it. Just remember that it's not a completely new experience and many things are similar to Borderlands 2, as my many mentions of it show. It runs on the same engine so that is expected. Also, performance is generally great. If you can run Borderlands 2, then this will be the same.

I guess this game can be summed up in one sentence: 'more of the same, but a bit worse'  I wanted to love this game, I really did. As a long-term Borderlands fan, I didn't want to accept that there was a Borderlands game that I didn't like. But there's SO. MUCH. about this game I don't like that I just... can't... bring myself to make this review positive.    I liked quite a few of the game's mechanics:    The gunplay and combat remains tight and engaging (although some enemies in UVHM - the third playthrough option - can feel like bullet sponges, where instead of intricate and challenging showdowns you're just holding fire until you win)    Character abilities are all pretty useful, especially Claptrap's now-infamous vaulthunter.exe, which is actually loads of fun and hella useful in certain situations   There's tons and tons and TONS of guns as to be expected (although some do just feel like retextured weapons from the previous games) and legendary weapon drop rates are quite high    There's more over-the-top characters and ridiculous (in a good way, promise) missions, particularly the Claptastic Voyage DLC which I'd recommend to hell and back if you're into Borderlands' recipe of what I'm calling 'serious silliness'    The dialogue between characters is pretty funny, and again there's pop culture references everywhere    Boosting around is admittedly quite entertaining for the first few hours of play    I LOVE the grinder. I think it's an awesome new mechanic that gives value to old, no-longer-needed loot, and often threw away stuff I needed at the prospect of making something even better   It's not a great game, however, far from it in my opinion;    Honestly, the main story completely failed to engage me. Most of the new characters are completely forgettable, and although I liked the development of    Jack and his transformation into Handsome Jack,    any mission not directly concerning this feels arduous and even irrelevant - there were a few missions I forgot entirely how what I was doing was relevant to the story    Returning chracters fail to add anything to the plot - I don't think any of them were utilised properly, and for the most part it feels like they've been cookie-cuttered into the story simply because they could be    The voice acting annoyed me for some reason. It wasn't the Australian accent thing (trust me, you'll notice 2K Australia played a part in this one), but most of the new voices and some of the returning ones    (ESPECIALLY MOXXI'S, RRRRGH SHE DOESN'T SHUT UP)    really tested my patience, especially when playing using headphones    As mentioned above, the low-gravity zero-oxygen gimmick becomes tiresome very quickly, when you realise you'll likely NEVER die from suffocation once you have an O2 kit as health drains so slowly you'd have to measure it's decline on a calendar, and oxygen filling points being as abundant as all sin, making 'Oz' kits an annoyance, not a strategy-changing mechanic. The 'butt-slam' (for lack of a more sophisticated term) is also woefully underpowered, and serves more as a way of clearing your path than a viable offence    I HATE THE DRIVING IN BORDERLANDS GAMES. I HATE IT SO SO MUCH. I've always hated the indescribably bizarrre vehicle controls and wonky, imprecise steering, and the gravity situation really doesn't help. The vehicles are too floaty, too fast and too uncontrollable, the steering (worsened no doubt by the gravity) is too wide, too weird and too inaccurate and you may as well just run/boost since most of the routes you'll be taking aren't too long    It... feels reall short. I don't know if it's because the side quests were really uninteresting, but the game felt like a less complete package, especially considering the contextually extortionate £30 price tag    I don't know why, but I just felt less compelled to explore than in previous titles. I felt like, since minibosses don't respawn, and there were no raid bosses at all, the risk of finding and fighting something that could kill you numerous times wasn't worth the payoff, especially when your loadout is mostly purple-rarity items, and you should never, ever, EVER feel like that in a game about exploring   Let me say it like this:   Did I enjoy this game? Yes, overall I was able to overlook the similarities and shortcomings (mainly because I wasn't prepared to accept I'd spent £30 on something I didn't like)  Would I recommend it to first-time Borderlands players? No. Go for Borderlands 2. Better story, better presentation, better combat, better DLC - better game, frankly  Would I recommend it to long-term fans looking for a fresh experience? Only if it goes on sale, paying full price like I did may set up expectations that ultimately won't be met  So yeah, Borderlands: TPS. More of the same, but a bit worse.

There are a lot of good single moments, but these are ALL in SIDE quests (such as explaining the origin of Jack's invisibility and how Nakayama got a scan of Jack's brain).  CONS:  - Very few decent guns. There are basically threee good unique guns, and you get them after you are levelled up beyond them.  - VERY annoying characters. Especially Pickle and Springs. I have Australian friends, I prefer the Australian audio track of Mad Max, I am totally capable of understanding Australian linguo and accent. I have no idea what Pickle is saying half the time and Springs is an insulting caricature.   - SHORT. Of all three games, this campaign in the shortest, and that's saying sometihng considering the next CON.  - You are locked in to dialogue. In the previoous games, you could continue down the road while everyone talked about the quest. In Pre-Sequel, you are stuck and cannot continue for as much as 10 minutes while characters talk to each other about crap that doesn't even matter. You do not get a waypoint and often you are trapped in a room with nothing while this goes on. In the words of Tiny Tina (who only appears via narration) in the second playthrough of the game, 'Uggh, so much boring talky talk, get back to the shooting.'  PROS:  - It fills in the story of what happened to a few things that didn't make an appearance in BL2. A few things.  - The Claptastic Voyage DLC. This is really the only reason to get the game and is what the main game should have been.  And that's pretty much it. There are only a couple fun quests.

First off, “Borderlands the Pre-Sequel “ in a nut shell is a copy and paste of “Borderlands 2” with a few additions to gameplay such as: New ice element (replaces slag), laser weapons, and space environments. At this moment, this game not worth $60 for any player expecting a fresh borderlands title. However future updates will likely improve the game so it is on par with Borderlands 2 quality. Currently, this game lacks a way to reset the story and side quest; making farming and replayability impossible without starting a new character.   Story: In actual time, this game takes place after Borderlands 2. One of the four new vault hunters, Athena, tells the story that took place between Borderlands 1 and 2. For any hardcore borderlands fans, this story is particularly important to understanding Handsome Jack’s viewpoint. In fact, if one would have never played borderlands 2 to witness his actions, one might feel sympathetic to Jack as he is the victim in Borderlands the Pre-Sequel.   Gameplay: Overall feel in terms of gun fights is identical to Borderlands 2. Many legendary items have been recycled from Borderlands 2. Classes are unique and well done; each having their own personality revealed as the game progresses. This explains a few of the bosses you face in Borderlands 2 and why they sided with Handsome Jack.  Nisha = Sheriff of Lynchwood also Jacks girlfriend in Borderlands 2 Wilhelm = Boss that appears in Borderlands 2 after the train crashed when you are in search of a power core. Claptrap and Athena are the only characters who left Jack’s side at the end of this game.  Hopefully new updates will bring this game on par with Borderlands 2. Right now this game is not worth $60 unless you are a hardcore fan of the series.

This is an absolute must have for any Borderlands fan. The Pre-Sequel is aptly named as it isn't quite a true sequel to Borderlands 2; the game's mechanics, graphics, and even items to some extent are all the same from Borderlands 2. However, for someone who loved the second game, this is the perfect continuation of the Borderlands we know and love, and has plenty of new features and content to keep you entertained. The classes are characters this time around are a real step up, with much more interesting skills, skill trees, dialogue, and costumes. The storyline is even better than BL2, and all of the bosses are crazy, colorful, and a ton of fun to fight. Despite some returning items, much of the loot is brand new, and the new lazer and cryo weapons are awesome to play with. The vehicles have also been given an upgrade, as the Moon Buggies feature much more powerful armaments than the vehicles of BL2, and the new Stingray is a blast to fly around in. As of right now, the only real con to the game is the fact that some of the bosses do not respawn, and are therefore non refarmable, however, Gearbox and 2K have already said they recognize the problem and are looking into a fix for it. Beyond that, the endgame does feel a bit empty, but this is customary of Borderlands pre DLC, and what with Gearbox's reputation and track record for incredible DLC, I am sure this is a situation that will be speedily rectified. In all, this is an incredibly fun game, either alone or with friends. Veterans and fans of the Borderlands series will love this 'Borderlands 2 2.0', and for players new to the series, this is the perfect place to jump in and start exploring the rich world of the Borderlands universe.

First of all, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is PRETTY much the same as Borderlands 2. There are differences here and there but ultimately if you enjoyed Borderlands 2, you'll enjoy this one.  That said, here's what's different, divided into Good additions and Bad additions.  GOOD: - The Stingray handles much like the sandskiff from the Captain Scarlett DLC in Borderlands 2, and it's definitely the best way to get around. The 'pancake' ability is mostly fluff, but it's fun early on when it can actually kill things.  - O2, surprisingly enough, isn't that annoying to manage. It ends up getting refilled constantly during battle since enemies drop O2 canisters, so it's only something to worry about when traveling, and even then if you run out you suffocate really, really slowly. Butt-stomping and jetting are fun additions, and Claptrap doesn't breathe, so you can play as him and mostly ignore the whole thing if you want.  - Cryo weapons are lots of fun, and replace Slag as the 'increase all other damage' element. Freezing a flying enemy and watching it shatter when it hits the ground is always fun.  - True Vault Hunter Mode doesn't just repeat the same flashback narration, but actually has new dialog. Which is better than the first playthrough.  - Legendaries can be found much more frequently in vending machines, meaning you're certain to pick up a few just through normal gameplay, and provides more use for money.   BAD: - The Moon Buggy handles like a drunk elephant. Once you unlock the Stingray, don't look back.  - Quest givers are scattered all over the various maps, so Concordia doesn't act like a hub as much as it should. BL2 had you constantly returning to Sanctuary to turn in all your quests at once.  - Similarly, quests will send you back to previous areas that you've since outleveled, making them into tedious chores. It's like the Matchstick quest in the BL2's Flame of the Firehawk quest chain, but repeated multiple times.  - Pickle. God damn Pickle. He won't shut up, and is representative of a recurring problem in the game in which NPCs blather on for WAY too long while you're just waiting for them to open the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ door or let you hand in your quest.   NEUTRAL: - The writing is much patchier this time around. There are plenty of excellent jokes, (TOOOOORGUE!) but you also have some really painful exchanges, (particularly those involving ♥♥♥♥ing Pickle,) that fall completely flat.  - The Grinder will eventually be your primary source of Legendaries, but by eventually I mean once you've hit the level cap and are able to farm bosses for lots and lots of moonstones. Until that point, it's a fun diversion that will occasionally give you something good but mostly will just spit out crap.  These are all essentially nitpicks, though. It's Borderlands. I like Borderlands. I like this game.

I thought BL2 was reaching the edge of what could be done. But The Pre-sequel carries on the tradition that started with BL1 even further. Having seen the evolution of gaming from the height of the arcade revolution in the 1980's, to the first home computers (Sinclair ZX81, Spectrum), right through to the eplosion of console gaming and now the PC. I think I can say that this game is a real *CLASS ACT*. The lasers reminded me of so many 'pew pew' arcade games and its nice to see a game that has an awareness of video game history. But man ! This thing is all over the place ! ... And like any powerful piece of artwork like the Mona Lisa or Dali paintings, I think sometimes it can induce some strong reactions from some who play it maybe misunderstanding what is going on. I've also heard complaints that the game is 'too short'. However when I was playing just before I found a hidden area with easter eggs. Exploration pays off and 2K Australia have done well to concentrate on the quality rather than pandering to those who have to play the game straight through as fast as possible. There's also some hilarious social satire here as well as an Australian theme (happen to like Australians so your milaeage may vary). What more can I say ? Bottom line for me is that I'm very impressed by the quality here of design and of course overall - *FUN*. The best way to play is just to play rather than stopping to analyse anything. Have fun !!

I wanted to like Borderlands: TPS. I really did. And I do - just not as much as I'd hoped. I played the hell out of the second game, and given that I expected TPS to be more of the same, I’m surprised that TPS didn’t grow on me more. TPS works on the same, successful formula – but it’s just too much of the same.  What to say? It’s Borderlands 2 with low-gravity, the same lucklustre plot and familiar enemy types. The low-gravity doesn’t make itself felt other than providing you more vertical routes throughout the game. The use of oxygen mechanics might as well not exist for all the difference it made to my gameplay.  Then the guns. Of course, it’s unfair to expect that what’s essentially another Borderlands 2 expansion pack will have as many guns as the second game, but the paucity of unique gun options was disappointing. There are some familiar favourites (the Quasar and Rolling Thunder grenades, the suicidal Nukem launcher, the pointless Invader), but if I wanted a rehash of BL2 weapons, I’d play BL2. There are the new Laser weapons, but my inventory just became inundated with them about halfway into my campaign. When everything’s a Maliwan-barrel laser beam that burns through ammo at an indecent rate, I start craving a simple sniper rifle or shotgun. They’re good, no question, but there was too much of it.  Essentially TPS suffers from the same things BL2 did. Perhaps playing so much of BL2 worked against me. I put down the second game having squeezed every drop of enjoyment out of it and had NO further desire to continue. Here TPS returns with exactly the same mission types. Go here – retrieve this or kill that – nearly get yourself killed – return. It was a formula that was tolerable in BL2 when I was new to the franchise, but it just doesn’t work on someone who’s played too much of BL2. TPS became a slog way before the halfway point.  Then there’s Jack, whom I was hoping to like more. I liked him in BL2 and was hoping to get more insight into why he became a murderous, flaming ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I enjoyed him as a villain but I’d have loved to sympathise with him as a character.  There isn’t any ‘why’ or ‘how’. Jack just IS a murderous, flaming ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. There’s no expansion at all on the details uncovered in BL2 about Jack’s wife and his daughter, Angel.  The plot hopes to explain Jack’s descent into insane megalomania. It doesn’t. Jack starts off with the appearance of being a harmless, bumbling idiot (his idiocy was reminiscent of a typical Claptrap unit) but he doesn’t really come across as being a hero at any point in the story. His desires have always come across as purely selfish. Even the ‘turning point’ (it seems), when he kills a familiar face and enjoys it, doesn’t come as much of a surprise. Borderlands is a bloodbath and always has been. The idea of Jack being a ‘good guy’, in any sense of the word, was dull and honestly, quite inconceivable (yes, it means what I think it means). And Jack is reduced to simply having been ‘good’ and later, ‘bad’.  Yet, on further thought, Jack isn’t even what I’d call evil. Callous, certainly, but he’s more of a bored child with big dangerous toys, too many lives in his hands and a very deadly sense of humour. Perhaps “childish” is the best adjective, really. The idea of descending into evil doesn’t really work in a game-verse that utilises black humour (somewhat) and trivialises death. Yes, Jack killed some of his old partners and develops an obsessive thirst for revenge. But who in Borderlands isn't a murderous madman?  And that’s Borderlands: TPS in a nutshell. “So what?”  Play it and forget it.  Rating: 5/10

For starters, there is an issue among players that I wish to address. This issue spurs from the idea that Borderlands Pre-sequel is supposed to be a long game, This issue spurs from HOW you play the game, I played through the first time doing every single side mission as well as the main quest line and finished the game in about 16 hours. Therefore if you just focus on the Main Quest line then of course your game will take less time and you will miss out on important character Development on Jack, Which is the WHOLE point of this game.   On another note, This gameplay is wholesome and accurate, There have been complaints about the use of the same UI for players, but honestly I LIKE that Gearbox kept the same UI because there was really no issue with it during the entire Borderlands 2 playthrough.  “If its not broken, Don’t fix it!”  The game has a lot of progressive factors, The use of low gravity seemed like a shaky idea but Gearbox pulled through and gave the player more control over movement and actually did a pretty damn good job at making the low gravity not interfere with gameplay and give a pretty beneficial aspect to the game that is often done incorrectly or just wrong by other game developers.  The characters are also very improved, there has been both incorporation of your character into the story and subtle dialogue differences that occur with each character.  If you are going to complain about the vehicle controls then you should just realise that this control is equivalent to each of the other games in the series.  The overall story of the game does a very good job at filling the gaps between the two games both incorporating past events on Pandora and allowing the players from Borderlands 2 to connect to future events that will have happened during the future game. The portrayment of Jack is especially well planned and expressed, no single event seems out of place and can connect to the larger web of events that ultimately develop Jack into the character that you remember from Borderlands 2. There is a development of Jack through events that cause the Hero Jack to become the Villain that is depicted in Borderlands 2. Now this does NOT mean that I solely like Jack as a villain, Jack plays a strong role as a hero within the game and is just as likeable if not more so overall, now that we have seen the two different and dichotomy-esque sides of Jack.  On a personal note, I appreciate Gearbox for the further explanation of the story of Jack who is arguably one of the best villain-esque characters from any video game, movie, or book that I know of.  10/10

I usually don't bother to write reviews, but this game is seriously broken on Linux. I would HIGHLY recommend that you don't purchase it if that's your platform of choice.  I loved Borderlands 2, and was incredibly excited that they released The Pre-Sequel for Linux.  That said... the game suffers from random freezing/stuttering. Ever so often (as frequently as every few minutes) the game will just freeze for several seconds. If you're hosting a game, the rest of the players can run around without you. If you're not hosting, you just lose out. It's frequent enough to make the game overall painful to play. Large portions of the game are based around jumping in low gravity... which doesn't work so well if your game stutters and you fall to your death.  There's no solution to be found, save for MAYBE disabling multiplayer, which evidently works for some people. Of course, then there's really no point to playing the game.  The stuttering occurs everywhere, even when all assets should be cached and the computer isn't taxed at all... like the main menu.  There's no way this ever should have been released in this state.  The game otherwise is OK. It's not fantastic like Borderlands 2 or really anything new, but it's fun to play with friends (or would be aside from the issues noted above). It doesn't seem to have the lasting appeal of Borderlands 2 either, though that impression may well be colored by the game being rendered borderline-unplayable by freezing.

To sum it up in one sentence, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is like a big DLC for borderlands 2. It has a lot of similarities, for example The UI is the same as the UI from borderlands 2, and some of the legendary weapons from the second game actually make a comeback into the Pre-Sequel (The Sham, Whiskey-Tango-Foxtrot, The Maggie, The Cracked Sash, The Neogenator, The Quasar, The Leech, and the Badaboom just to name a few). However, the Pre-Sequel also adds a new weapon type, lasers, into the game, and adds a new element as well, called cryo. While the story isn't as amazing as Borderlands 2's story, you still get to work with Jack before he became Hyperion's CEO, and get to watch his slow decent into the power hungry villain that most people are familiar with from the second game. The Pre-Sequel takes place after the first Borderlands but before the second, however you should still play the second game (and maybe the first) before playing this one, as many, many refrences to things that happen in Borderlands 2 are explained in the Pre-Sequel (the origin of Hyperion's Robot army, The creation of the constructors, and why Jack wears a mask). There are a few glaring problems that the game has, most notably Pickle (he's a ten year old NPC you meet in the game and he is TERRIBLE.) and low gravity. Due to the fact that the game takes place mostly on Elpis, Pandora's moon, you will be jumping around at low gravity for most of it. Some people like the Jumping around at low gravity, but for the most part it's just 2k's way of adding more depth into the game, which doesn't really work effectively. overall, the game is a solid 7.5/10. I'd say buy it, but only when it goes on sale.  (By the way the Claptastic Voyage DLC is amazing, you should definitely get it!)

I am going to make this a simple review, as i dont normally do them.  First i'm going to explain a little backstory, if you just want the pros and cons just skip this, it explains my history with the Borderlands games. Then later on i bought a friend the DLC and played with him and had loads of fun, and continued to play with others as well. I then went and replayed through the first and second game on stream with a group of freinds at  www.insomniacgamers.net  and it was a blast. We looked forward to play through the Pre-Sequel together.  Now lets get o the pros and cons. Pros:  -Like Borderlands 2 but in space. -New weapons and items, the grinder was interesting but limited. -Some backstory to events in Borderlands 2 -Claptrap -Characters actually respond to whats going on.  Cons: -Everybody sounds the same, everybody but previously known characters are australian. It gets on your nerves eventually. -Story felt like the beginning and end were thought out but everything inbetween was thrown together at a moments notice. -Claptrap -Too many badasses, if everybody is a badass then nobody is a badass. Now you may think 'This has more negatives than positives, why is it a positive review?' That is because its a fun game and i would play it again if only the a quad claptrap group. I feel the negatives do stick out more but they arent as bad as they at first seem. What i do hope is that the DLC makes up for the lackluster middle of the game. I would say a good price to buy this game is anywhere between $30 and $45, it didnt feel like a $60 game or even a $50 game. Honestly, I think this game was one of the biggest disappointments I've ever faced in the gaming world. I was so excited for the new BL game to come out, I didn't think that Gearbox would let it just die like it did. Pros: -I really liked the new gravity and oxygen dynamics, they made combat more interesting for a little bit. -Talkative characters. Having the correspondence between the Vault Hunters and the environment was a nice change, and you could see in BL2 that they were trying to make this more of a reality in Tiny Tina's DLC with the Vault Hunters having small moments where they responded to the narration. -Good story, playing as the bad guys helped to further the whole 'moral gray area' idea that BL presents.  Cons: -The gravity dynamic was fun at first, but got old in the further levels of the game. As well, it was unpredictable and inconsistent, and caused a lot of unnecessary death in trying to explore or while driving. -That thing where they arbitrarily shove as much social justice into the game as possible and expect it to be okay. (ie. too many homosexuals, killing people for being intolerant, extreme bias, making jabs at the player, etc.) I could understand a subtle prod here and there, but all out revealing that you're nothing more than tumblristas in a half-done game seems like a dangerous move when no one is excited for any other developments you have on the horizon. -Too short. It was about half as long as BL2, and shorter than BL1 by a long shot, so I barely even had time to get engaged with the story. Also, releasing a short game isn't always a big deal, but when it's a game where most players expect to be buying DLC hot off the market, the game should be longer than a DLC itself. I'm glad that I only spent $30 on this during a sale rather than the whole 60. I would rather have bought it as a DLC for 2, and paid the same amount. -Not really worth the time. Yes, it works as a nice segue into Borderlands 3, but besides that, it was tedious. Traversing the moon was fun, but then you discover it's barely big enough to actually call exploring. And, above that, I had no motivation to replay the game because I just didn't care enough. I won't be buying the level cap increase, as there's not even enough to do in the game to get to level 61. And even if I did get to that level, I wouldn't want to play an empty game with no farmable bosses and hardly any loot. -Boring enemies. All the enemies are the same, and all the creatures are annoying. -Australian accents are not that funny, nor is their lingo, it got played out very quickly. -The whole story is supposed to revolve around Athena's retelling of it to the original Vaulters, but I played as Wilhelm, so it was a let down to feel like my character isn't even involved in the cut scene after the final boss is killed, or in most of the actual story besides his little conversations with Jack. -Plot holes. Why even make Felicity able to talk? She was worthless to the story, could have just used any old AI rather than present it as an important character, then drop it from the game entirely.  There's no way to fix this game without completely redoing the story and making it longer, less SJW, and maybe using some diversity, so there's no way to fix it. I don't want to wait till BL3 comes out to care about this franchise again, so maybe there should be some free DLC released, or make the DLC's that inevitably come out last 15 hours each.  Overall, 6/10

This Pre-Sequel is not the same quality as the previous Borderlands. It feels cheap and untested for the majority of its game play and has quite a few outstanding issues: Geometry problems (vehicles going off the map), mobs shooting/running/flying through structures and various terrain glitches just to name a few engine based issues. I personally on SteamOS have problems with some Guns' rate of fire suddenly changing in the middle of a fight for no apparent reasons. For the AI, enemies love flying and they also love getting stuck while flying or they just stop doing whatever they were doing to give you time to shoot them down. (pretty)  This release of Borderlands also adds a few mechanical gimmicks, the main one being the low gravity and the absence or presence of an atmosphere. Unfortunately it just doesn't work very well, Your character is supposed to benefit from the low gravity using an Oz kit. Using the Oz kit you can apparently fly, move quickly across terrain etc... This is probably true, if you are an enemy. You on the other hand don't fly or move quicker. It feels like you're stuck with Marry Poppins' Umbrela and all your enemies have Tribe based jet packs. The low gravity/lack of atmosphere thing ends up turning combat into Stay Puft Marshmallow Man vs An annoying bunch of prepubescent kids.  Combine the slow motion fights with the few vehicles in the game and you've got quite a contrast and it's not to say that vehicle combat is any better. In most fights with vehicle weapon systems, you can stop, aim, put the vehicle in reverse, step back a little, aim, kill and you're done. The combat is just massively disappointing in Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. It is slow and not exciting at all.  A few reviews out there have been stating that level design is confusing, well I disagree. It's just dumb. So if you approach levels the dumbest way you can, you shouldn't be confused at all. One of the most frustrating feature from these levels is how checkpoints are distributed and how some of it forces you to walk an entire map back if you die while others are right next to each other.  Really disappointed with this game, I was expecting better quality, but it looks like it was basically thrown out to fans just to wrap up the Borderlands franchise. I'm happy I got the title at a discount and I wouldn't recommend this game at full price to any hardcore Borderlands fan.
This is a very nice addition to the Borderlands wheelhouse. If you are a fan of the series, this won't disapoint you.

Played through it blind while clearing all side missions; took around 17-18 hours, post final story mission. It's okay. Spoiler-free below.  If you want to learn more about Handsome Jack's origin story, this game provides context. Other than that, it didn't feel as fun or relatable as Borderlands 2. A lot more female characters and accents this time around, yet none of the characters really stood out. I played through Athena's story, and it felt lackluster. Then again, most, if not all, character back stories in the Borderlands lore are lacking.  Oxygen system felt more of a nusciance than anything else. Didn't experience asphyxiation at all during the game, but the system just felt annoying. The majority of the game is spent in low gravity anyhow, so oxygen is somehow relevant? Speaking of, with a lot of the game in low gravity, a lot of the movement comes out slow and floaty. Even though Borderlands 2 had this, its more prominent in this game. Be expected to spam double jumps and slams just to seem fast.  Mechanically, without slag, there's less reliance on damage amp and moreso on various effects. There wasn't a time when I was boned without the proper elemental effect, because the game does its job on making sure you're not without the right elemental type. Quests will allow for fire/cryo/electric/etc. weapons if needbe, so there's no need to hunt for a certain element.  The map definitely feels smaller this time around, and to get around this, the side quests feel heavily back-tracky. A lot of the time, side quests will pop up in areas that you've already cleared in the main story, multiple times. Not much to explore, so might as well do it repeatedly. With a lack of multiple TPs in areas, I saved, quit, and then resumed a lot just to hop to fast travel points. Sucks, but beats having to jump all over the place.  If you're a fan of the series, play this for continuity. If you enjoyed Borderlands 2 for the writing but not the overall series for the world and lore, skip over this.  Also, laser OP.

Imma be a little generic here: Like everyone else says, this game is worse than BL2. HOWEVER... However, there are upsides.  Pros: -The classes: the classes in this game are honestly much more creative than in BL2 (exception, Krieg; Krieg was pretty unique). Example, Claptrap. Claptrap was the support character no one needed but even with that you still probably wanted to play him, thanks to his zany ability to be a 'Vault Hunter' using Vault_Hunter.exe. Wilhelm was like the Axton of BL2, but with pets that actually were useful and took the advantage of flying 24/7  -The weapons: not the actual weapons themselves, but the ease of access to higher ranking weapons. Also the lazers, which honestly IS a fun addition.  -The gear: as much as the Oz kits and system is nothing spectacular, the actual usage of them, personally, was much grander than the relics in BL2. This would have to be because they actually needed in active role in using them, making you much wiser to what you would put in that slot. Shields were subpar but I'll get into that in the 'cons.' Grenades really added nothing new until you got legendaries. Lengendary grenades really amped the field. While not superior to BL2 grenades, however superior to BL1 grenades, they were fun to use with their (sometimes) randomness.  The Cons: -Shields: this is touchy, since shields in BL2 in late game get iffy and less reliable. The shields seemed to decreases in quality, though being more combat effective. A good purple shield would do you just as good as the legendaries I've gotten my hands on, unlike in BL2 where the shields showed drastic change and had importance.  -Late game/Aftermath: this is simply  *Two bosses, one of which is just beating the end boss again (sorry for minor spoiler)  *One story DLC (which I will not remark on as I don't own nor seen it)  -Story Bosses: this may just be me, but the story bosses you encounter get substantially harder and more co-op intensive. And while I love playing a good co-op match, I'd like to be able to fight bosses on my own and not die many many many times (on the first playthrough at that!) No spoilers, there is one boss where the best way to win is standing on a cursed platform hoping to get hits off at it... super... slowly...  Overall Thoughts?: Overall, yeah I would recommend this game... if you're already a fan of the franchise. As everyone else who recommends this game, play the other two first. Become a fan or else you might end up hating this game (and the franchise which is good as a whole, honestly) and therefore wasting money.   PS(Unrelated to being a review): I'm ALWAYS open to playing a good co-op match in this game, so feel free to invite me if you do buy this. Completely willing to start a new character too for those wanting fresh playthroughs. :)

I got into this game right away. It seemed pretty cool at the start.  I had dreams of playing through with all 4 characters. Then buying two DLC to get two more. I have played way too many hours of Borderlands 1 & 2 that I was confident I was making the right choice to play this one.  Now, I'm not so sure. It just seems that there are a lot more opportunities to die in this one. I don't mean getting killed by the opponents...that's 'OK'. It's getting killed because you fell or jumped wrong that bothers me. It really sucks the fun out of it.  Pros: - It's Borderlands! IF you have played the others, you know how to play this. - They introduced the oxygen limit. Not a biggy, but it does give you some extra incentive to move through an area.  Cons: - They have made this a 3D platform game. There are too many timed missions (side missions, thank goodness) But, other missions require timing jumps and such. Fail and die. Yes, there are LOTS of them in the OTHER games, but at least you don't die if you fail. - Timing is WAY too critical. The first time I got the Stingray I thought it would be great to jump. But, it's almost worse than the moon buggy. I died countless times trying to jump a gap to get to Dave. - Navigation is poor. I thought it was very neat when I got to Concordia and they displayed some waypoints to show you how to get to the roof; later in the giant spaceship you end up going 'off the map' to get to where you need to. And you have to repeat the process several times. Sometimes it was not clear that you had to go north to go south! - Voices on the characters were VERY hard to understand. I turned the music way low so I could hear the characters, but finally had to turn on the subtitles to figure out what they were saying. - I ended up dying a LOT. Probably about 100 times more than I did in the other Borderlands. It's way too easy to jump a bit too far and plummet to your death - especially INSIDE the spaceship. - I spend too much time going to the web trying to figure out how to get to the next part of a mission. I should be playing, instead. - They kept the same 'Badass' rep from Borderlands 2. Sure, you can turn it off, but then it's off for ALL of your characters. I really like the way Borderlands 1 did it; the more you used a particular weapon type the better THAT character got with that type of weapon. Made a lot more sense. I like this game more than Borderlands 2. YES. Borderlands 2 has WAY WAY WAYYY more content but for what this game has it is amazing! The low gravity makes combat far more dynamic than in BL2. Now you have all three dimensions to maneuver in, making combat interesting,  Do I want to jump over my enemies and attack them from above?  Do I want to evade my enemies by jumping to vantage points and attacking them from there?  Or do you just want to run up and slam them away with the new slam mechanic?  Not only that the environments are more dynamic. Air is a resource that you must keep an eye on making some situations more intense then it would be in BL2. Also you can use the environment as a weapon. And I’m not talking about ye olde explosive barrels. You can shoot the enemies air supply and cause a suffocation DOT.  As for elemental gimmicks, fire will do big DOT damage if the enemy is in Air, and then we have Cyro, the best element in Borderlands history!  Know what was fun about slag? Nothing. I HATED always having to tug around a slag weapon in Borderlands 2.  To me, being forced to use a gun I don’t want to use, slagging the enemy, and then switching to a gun I actually want to play with is not fun. (True you could argue this is only required in Ultimate vault hunter mode, but that’s where the real game is at.) Know what is fun? Freezing your enemy, and them punching them in the face and watching them shatter into a million pieces. That’s Cyro. The freezing element that is one part crowd control, one part melee wet dream. I have over 210 hours on BL2 and so far NOTHING is as satisfying than freezing a badass and then robot punching them in the face with Wilhelm and watching them shatter.  As for the world… Pandora felt too much like Earth. You could replace all the alien animals with Earth animals and you could totally fool someone into thinking the game takes place on Earth. Elpis however… feels truly alien.  Also I found the character Wilhelm interesting. The more you level him up in his cyper commando tree the more robotic he becomes and his voice even changes. I have never seen that in any other BL character. (Physically changing as you level them)  Also laser weapons are etech weapons except they don’t suck and come in 4 different forms. (Assult rifle, ghostbustery beams, sniper, and shotguns)   So…  Pros  -3 dimensional fighting  - environments are fun to fight in and the O2 mechanic makes you more aware of your surroundings - Running around a low gravity moon is fun -Wilhelm (200 of my hours were just on him)  -Cyro being the best element ever.  -lasers!   Cons - Far less content than BL2  - Not as hard as BL2  YES BL2 is the better game because of the content, BUT if you compare the games at their cores, Pre sequel is superior with my opinion.

Nonetheless, it still is fun!

I honestly wish there was a 'Neutral' option on the recommend for Steam, as this game falls into that for me, not the best, not the worst.  Being a fan of Borderlands (owning all the games and most of the DLC's) I was quite hyped to play Pre-Sequel, expecting more of the great times I had while playing BL1&2, however, I honestly struggled to enjoy the game at first, being on the moon, the story not pulling me in (well, not straight away) and I finding the default four characters to be boring, and having no friends who wanted to play the game, made me walk away from the game for a long time.  However, After a long time without paying attention to the game, and during a steam sale, I saw the 'Handsome Jack' DLC, which being a fan of him, I paid and tried again, now having a character who intrested me and had a decent skill tree (for me) made the game playable, and once you actually get a little ways into it, it does become enjoyable and the story picks up (tho the end boss to me just felt...kinda weird and out of place for some reason).  Without going on too long as I have a habit to do, I'd say this game is fun, enjoyable and still has enough of a Borderlands feel to it, but suffers from the whole 'moon gameplay WOO!' vibe, being away from Pandora and the characters we know and love hurt the game in my opinion (and the new characters bore me SO much, wanted to tell Springs to bugger off many a time), the story does give me enough insight into Jack to be enjoyable and kept me from not recommending the game. (I always feel though that if a game NEEDS a DLC to make me enjoy it, its not doing good enough in the first place.)  Overall I'd say if you really love Borderlands or don't mind it being a little less intresting than the other parts of the series, grab it and have some fun, getting the DLC's helps improve the game IMO, but I'd only recommend this game when its at least 50% off, not worth the full price.  (Ratings wise, I'd give it a 6/10 for the base game and a 7.5/10 with DLC's added)

Borderlands the Pre-Sequel is not an entirely bad Borderlands game. There are many things in this game that deserve praise, but many others that just makes you wonder why Gearbox decided to put it in. The game excels in many things, one of which is the story, as it shows how Handsome Jack became Handsome Jack and puts a bit of backstory on many other characters. It is a lot like the other games in the series, but that also ends up being a con, as there are no major differences between the gameplay of The Pre-Sequel and Borderlands 2.  Pros - Vault Hunters have much more interesting dialog. There is a great soundtrack, if you listen. The laser and cyro weapons are pretty interesting and fun to use. There are unique and more interesting enviroments, with many cool features. Claptrap is SO annoying (and I love it). The Doppleganger class is one of the best, and I would definitely recommend using it. Low gravity sections.  Cons - Low gravity sections. Story is extremely short, maybe 15 hours at a normal pace. Missions seem to be stretched out. Not enough areas to explore. The grinder isn't that good, and I've lost good guns to it to get a worse one. NO SLAG. WHY DID THEY REMOVE SLAG?  All-in-all, it isn't a bad game, it just has many crucial flaws. I would say it isn't worth $40, and if you wanted to buy it, buy it on sale.

Alright.... Where do I start...  Do I want my money back? No. Did I have fun? Yeah. Was it painful to watch your favorite game stripped of it's humor and charm? Also yes. The new classes were the reason I kept going. I had to switch from Athena to Wilhelm though because I couldn't take Athena's bland 'voice-acting' and 'character development', assuming there was any. Look, I guess I enjoyed myself, but when I opened up borderlands 2 for the first time since I bought the pre-sequel, I realized what I was missing.

It's pretty good. At this point you know what to expect from the last ones, this is more of that. There's nothing ground breaking here but that's not necessarily a bad thing. Abilities and classes feel better flushed out and unique. The low gravity makes walking around much more enjoyable. Some of the additional backstory on characters keeps the story interesting.   I'm more frustrated with inventory management in this one than the previous 2. Previously they allowed weapons/items to be marked with star, X, or nothing, they got rid of X. Sounds minor but this has been incredibly frustrating for me because of how I deal with inventory. While the inventory management has always been bad, being able to make star = keep, X = sell, nothing = I haven't reviewed it yet. That way I can quickly go through items and know what I need to compare and when I go to sell I can easily sell it. Without X, effectively I can only mark what I want to keep. Meaning I can't tell what I want to get rid of vs what I haven't compared yet. So I compare once when I get new gear and again before I sell because I don't remember if the nothing marked ones are all ones I wanted to get rid of or something I haven't reviewed.   Other than that, I have some minor gripes but they don't hugely distract or frustrate. If you like Borderlands, you'll like this one.

If you like the Borderlands series AT ALL, then you will love this game. I have played quite a few games again which I initially did not like, and either still disliked them, or found a way to dislike them even more. However, it's incredibly rare that I revisit a game and find myself  really  enjoying it upon trying it again. I did about 1.5 playthroughs of the Pre-Sequel (which is kinda funny, since the game is '1.5' in the series, so there's that), and simply did not enjoy the game. I thought it felt like Borderlands 2 in a crappy setting, and never wanted to play it again. Someone insisted he wanted to play it again, and, wanting to have something to gripe about, I offered to play through it with him so I could complain about the game some more. However, I ended up doing three whole playthroughs of the game, and would like to do more.  What changed? The only thing I can think of that's any different is my expectations...and I didn't play as Claptrap. Although a lot of people find him annoying as a character, period, I actually really like him. However, as a vault hunter, I didn't like his skill tree all that much. Of course, my half-playthrough was as Nisha, and I think most people enjoy playing as her, so I don't know. As for my expectations, though, Borderlands 2 had an amazing plot compared to Borderlands 1, and the maps had a lot of environmental variation. In The Pre-Sequel, however, the moon is rocky...all over. There's not a lot of map variation, so that is still a negative, and the plot, though decent, wasn't as good as Borderlands 2.  Gameplay-wise, though, I played through the normal difficulty and True Vault Hunter mode with Athena, and the normal difficulty with the Baroness (DLC character who makes cryo element wonderful), and  loved  my time as them. Their skill trees and skills were a ton of fun, and the guns in this game are great, because...well, because they pretty much did copy-paste everything from Borderlands 2 about the guns, then added a laser gun type and called it a day. The low-gravity jumping and quasi-double-jumps were fantastic, and I would actually love to see something like that in the next Borderlands game. Although a lot of stuff felt lazy in his game because it's identical to Borderlands 2, getting new vault hunters, a cryo element that's way better than the slag element it replaces, and various nice gameplay features make this a really enjoyable game.  It's rare that I change my mind from severe disappointment to high appreciation, but it happened here. Thank you for existing, The Pre-Sequel, and I'm sorry I hated on you before. <3

The game is... well, it's good. But its good because Borderlands 2 was good, and this is basically Borderlands 2 with a scant few additions, a much smaller amount of DLC, and a different, but related, story.  In conclusion, I really mainly recommend this game if you are really interested in the lore of Borderlands 2 and wanted to like Jack, or at least see how far he actually fell.
